subdebate.1.para: Senator MCCLELLANDpresented from 1 14 citizens of New South Wales a petition showing that the decision of the Government to lift the 40-year ban on the export of merino rams will do irreparable harm to the present and future merino wool industry of Australia; that the initial quota of 300 rams will be sufficient to make any future protest worthless; and that the production of fine medium quality merino wool in cheap labour countries will put the Australian merino wool grower and ail connected with this industry out of business. The petitioners pray that the Government will cause to be held a referendum of wool growers to determine this issue.
Petition received and read.

talk.start.para: - My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. How does it come about that there is a prohibition against Australian senators and members of the House of Representatives visiting joint AustralianUnited States installations in Australia, such as Woomera, when there is no such prohibition against United States senators and representatives visiting such installations?

- I am certain that the honourable senator's question is based on a false premise. There is no prohibition on Government or Opposition senators or members of the House of Representatives visiting Woomera. Indeed, the general public can visit Woomera in certain circumstances after making the normal representations. I think the honourable senator is making some presumptions in relation to future proposals for a certain area in Woomera. His question is completely hypothetical. If he has in mind the Pine Gap establishment - his question was not directed to that but I shall give him a little supplementary infor mation - the situation is that some visits were made to that area in the early stages. I visited the establishment myself, as did also Mr Whitlam. The Minister for Defence, in answer to a written question by the honourable member for Yarra, Dr Cairns, in another place, set out the conditions in relation to Pine Gap and I do not feel that I need to add anything here to what he said in response to that question.

- I address a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the deteriorating drought position in Queensland and the need for urgent action, can the Minister inform the Senate when a decision can be expected from the Federal Government with relation to the request from the Queensland Government for assistance?

- Yesterday I was asked a question in relation to this matter and 1. indicated that the Government was considering representations that were being made to the Commonwealth by the Queensland Government. 1 acknowledge, as I think we all do, that a serious drought condition has prevailed and is still prevailing in a part of Queensland. In another place this morning, I think, the same question was directed to the Prime Minister and he made a statement in relation to the matter. 1 have not the complete text of what he said, but I am quite certain thai a statement will be made by the Prime Minister's Department on this matter. My understanding is that a short time ago the Prime Minister advised the Parliament that the Commonwealth Government had indicated to the Queensland Government not only a recognition of the drought conditions that prevail there but also that the Commonwealth will make a substantial contribution to that State. I repeat that at this point of time 1 am not relying on the precise detail of the statement, but my understanding of the announcement by the Prime Minister was that the Commonwealth will agree to an extension of Commonwealth assistance to cover freight rate rebates on the movement of non-starving stock for slaughter from drought areas. If the State wishes to proceed with a scheme for the sale of wheal to drought affected farmers on 12 months credit at 4}%, the Commonwealth will ask the Wheat Board to institute such a scheme. The Commonwealth will be prepared to meet one half the expenditure in 1968-69 lip to $4m plus the whole of the expenditure in 1968-69 in excess of $4m on this special drought relief. There was also an indication that it will throw open the Shoalwater area which is held by the Commonwealth Government to provide additional food for stock in that area.

- I address a question to the Leader of the Government. Does the statement made yesterday in another place by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Anthony, that negotiations are proceeding with the wool industry on implementing merino ram exports mean that the Government will ignore the adverse Senate vote? As obviously legislation to lift the ban would be rejected by the Parliament, is the position that the Cabinet believes its executive power overrides Parliament? Would the Minister agree that this raises serious constitutional issues?

- It is true that the relationship between the two Houses is a constitutional matter. As I understand the position if, by way of resolution, the Senate expresses a view or takes action in relation to a Bill, then quite clearly this is a matter that has to be considered by the Government. I think it would be premature to make any assumptions in relation to the obvious consideration that the Government will have of a resolution that was passed in this place, but I do fee] that the honourable senator may be reading into the statement made by Mr Anthony something which would not be intended. Mr Anthony has made a statement of the proposal. The Senate has expressed a view about it and. in the normal processes of our constitutional bicameral system of government, the views of the Senate will obviously be considered by the Government

- I address my question to the Leader of the Government. I refer to the answer given by him to the Leader of the Opposition concerning access to the joint defence facility at Woomera which has been the subject of discussion in Parliament this week. I suggest to the Minister that his answer has left us all very much in the dark. I would like to ask him specifically: Is there to be a prohibition against Australian senators and members of Parliament visiting this installation? Further, will there or will there not be a prohibition against US senators and congressmen visiting the installation?

- Yesterday I was asked a question about the statement made in another place and I said that I was not prepared to make any comments beyond what was in the statement. The facts are that Woomera at present is under the jurisdiction of my Department. There are restrictions on entry to the Woomera complex but they are not restrictions which preclude visits by parliamentarians under certain conditions. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is trying to draw me into a debate or argument as to what the future holds in relation to a proposed establishment in the Woomera area. Quite frankly 1 am not going to respond to that attempt because I rely completely on what was said in the statement made in the other place in relation to this matter.

- My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Postmaster-General, relates to the allocation of free time on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's radio and television stations for use by political parties in making their claim to office known to the Australian public. Will the Minister discuss with the Postmaster-General the proposition that he and the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission review completely the present criteria in accordance with which the Commission allocates time for this purpose, so that all recognised political parties in the State and Federal Parliaments may receive an adequate allocation of time and so that the claim for time by recognised independent members will not be disregarded?

- The honourable senator's question refers to the time allocated to political parties for Australian Broadcasting Commission broadcasts. He has expressed the view that adequate time should be given to representatives of all recognised parties. I will place this question and the honourable senator's opinion before the Postmaster-General and discuss the matter with him.
- I ask the

speech.para: Leader of the Government whether he can advise the Senate of the future sitting days of the Senate, and particularly of the possible rising date in May. Does the Government expect that the Parliament will rise on Thursday, 22nd May or Thursday. 29th May? The Minister will realise the importance of this matter in order that honourable senators will be in a position to arrange their work and their electoral programme.

talk.start.para: - At the moment my understanding of the arrangements is thai we will rise this afternoon and will not sit next week. Then we will have 3 weeks of sittings which will take us to 29th May. 1 cannot give more accurate information than that at this time. If there is a possibility of the Parliament rising earlier, obviously I will make that information available as soon as possible to the leaders of other parties and, indeed, to the whole Senate. For the purpose of future planning by honourable senators - and I recognise they all have commitments when we are not in session - they may assume that Parliament will be sitting until 29th May.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Has the Government received a request from the Tasmanian Government for a grant or other assistance towards the construction of a rail link from Launceston to its container feeder port and its general port at Bell Bay? If not, can the Minister indicate whether the Commonwealth Government would give consideration to such a request if it were made by the Government of Tasmania?

- From time to time questions are directed to me about representations made by various States to the Commonwealth for special assistance to carry out special projects. I always reply - and I reply in the same terms today - that these matters are dealt with at the Prime Minister-Premier level. The normal procedure is for the Premier to make repre sentations to the Commonwealth by directing his request to the Prime Minister. It goes without saying that all representations made by a Premier to the Prime Minister are given consideration. Quite clearly, when a Premier believes that the Commonwealth should be asked for a subvention, the responsibility or the onus in the first instance is on that Premier to make his representations. I can say no more than that in this regard.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Labour and National Service, who will recall that on 27th March 1 asked him a question about a worker's compensation claim made by a Canberra man named Busico. fs the Minister in a position to reply?

- I am in a position to inform the honourable senator thai the employee to whom he refers was employed by a person who had not funds to meet any judgment for common law compensation that might be awarded against him. The employer also had no effective insurance against workers' compensation payments. Under the relevant Ordinance, therefore, the liability fell on the nominal insurer, an authority established to cover cases where default occurs in the payment of workers' compensation. In the case in question there was a mistaken impression that the Century Insurance Company Ltd was liable to cover the claim for worker's compensation payments. The employee first received $1,586 in worker's compensation, and since has received $8,974 in worker's compensation. He is entitled to and is continuing to receive a weekly payment of $38.25 in worker's compensation. I am advised that he is entitled to receive this weekly payment for an indefinite and in fact unlimited period. There is, in the Australian Capital Territory, no ordinance comparable with the New South Wales legislation requiring compulsory insurance against common law damages.
- Why not?
- That matter is receiving immediate consideration.
- It has taken 20 years.

- The honourable senator who interjects could have moved in this Parliament for an amendment of the law at any time since he first entered Parliament. 1 do not remember his raising his voice to express an opinion that the law should be amended. Now that an incident has occurred to direct attention to the deficiency, the Government is giving urgent consideration to remedying that deficiency.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Labour and National Service. Has the Minister seen a report that the Municipal Roads Board and Parks Employees Union has complained to the Perth Shire Council about the appointment by that Council of women street cleaners? Is it a fact that the union has asked for an assurance that men will be employed in these positions and that if no men are available women will be employed only on a temporary basis? Does the Minister consider that this is clear proof that any move made by the Australian Council of Trade Unions or by any individual trade union to gain equal pay for equal work performed by women is merely a cunning device to ensure that men will always be assured of employment in preference to women if the women arc to bc given equal remuneration?

- I regret that I have not noticed the information to which the honourable senator has referred. As to the implications of 1his claim, all I wish to say is that it shows a clear failure to recognise the undoubted value of women in respect of such work.
- Can the Minister for Works give me any information in relation to my recent plea for Commonwealth assistance to combat serious erosion in the Greenwell Point section of the Shoalhaven River?

- It will be recalled that on 16th April during the adjournment debate Senator Mulvihill directed my attention to this matter. It appears that the Shoalhaven River was diverted some time ago by means of a canal about a mile in length. The joining of that canal with the Crook- haven River, I think it is, has created some risk of flood damage to a flat area which is used to a considerable degree by tourists and on which there are a number of holiday homes. The State Government has relegated its responsibility in this instance to the Shoalhaven Shire Council and therefore, of course, we in the Federal sphere must abstain from any direct interference, lt will be satisfactory to the Senate, however, to be reminded that in 1964 the Commonwealth allocated to New South Wales the sum of $5. 5m to enable flood mitigation works to be carried out over a period of 6 years on various New South Wales rivers, including the Shoalhaven River. The distribution of that SS.Sm was a responsibility of the New South Wales Government. I understand that the Shoalhaven Shire received SL.Im but the Shire has not been able to utilise those funds for this particular work. I think the honourable senator will be satisfied that, for the present at any rate, the Commonwealth has made a fairly substantial contribution. As I have pointed out, the priority of allocation is really a matter for the State Government or the Shire Council.

- My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate relates to an answer he gave yesterday to a question concerning the availability of Commonwealth publications in capital cities. The Minister said that there is a government bookshop in Melbourne and Sydney. Can he inform the Senate whether there are government bookshops in other capital cities in Australia? Will the Government consider establishing shops in the principal provincial cities in Australia where a large variety of Government publications would be readily available to the Australian public, as is the case in provincial towns in New Zealand where most government publications are readily available for sale? Alternatively, will the Government contact the existing private bookshops throughout Australia with a view to their establishing special sections to retail government publications?

- Yesterday I provided an answer to Senator Cavanagh which had been given to me very kindly by the Principal Parliamentary Reporter. It had a particular reference. The question now asked has a far wider application and I would need it to be placed on notice so that it could be evaluated and consideration given to the proposals made by the honourable senator.

- I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Do any resignations from the Public Service have to be approved by the Governor-General? If so, what grades of public servants have to receive such approval before resigning?

- The nature of the question indicates that it should go on notice in order that a considered reply can be obtained. Quite clearly the question should be directed to the Prime Minister because it relates to the Public Service Board.

- My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows on questions asked by the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition regarding the establishment of a joint United States-Australian defence space communications facility at Woomera. In the light of discussions in this chamber on Tuesday of this week, I ask: Has the Leader of the Government received a request from the Leader of the Opposition for time to be allotted for a debate on this subject? If not, is he able to say whether the absence of any such request is due to the well known division within the ranks of the Opposition as to the Opposition's policy on this subject?

- On Tuesday I read to the Senate the statement that the Prime Minister had made on the subject in the other place and the Leader of the Opposition moved that the Senate take note of the paper, which is the normal procedure in this chamber. The Leader of the Opposition also raised the question of a debate on the paper and I replied that I would be most willing and anxious to make time available for a debate at an appropriate time. The fact of the matter is that the Senate will not be sitting next week. If the Leader of the Opposition indicates to me when the Senate resumes its sittings that the Opposition would like to have a debate on the subject, with the concurrence of the Senate I shall make time available for it.

- I wish to direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister aware of the direct conflict between the Department of External Affairs and the Department of External Territories on the matter of refugees from West Irian? Will this conflict lead to increased tension in this area of New Guinea?

- I have seen the Press reports on the subject. 1 noticed that one newspaper in particular played up the point that there are different views on the affairs at the border between New Guinea and West Irian. I believe that this could be due to interpretation. The Minister for External Affairs made it abundantly clear at a Press conference that the discussions that he had had with the Indonesian Foreign Minister had resulted in the situation being reached where, rather than tension increasing, there will be a diminution or removal of any tensions which are indicated in some of the articles that I have read in the Press. Indeed, I have a transcript of the Press conference that occurred on the Minister's return, ft is a very lengthy document. I would be happy to make it available to the honourable senator. The transcript clearly reveals that everything is being done to mitigate the situation which occurred in that area and that due regard is being had to the personnel who crossed the frontier. I understand that accommodation will be made available to them until such time as they make their own judgment on what they desire to do.

- My question is directed to the Minister for Housing. Can the Minister state what truth, if any, there is in the statement reported to have been made by the Tasmanian Labor Minister for Housing, Mr Ward, which appeared in the Hobart 'Mercury' of 30th April that the attitude of the Federal Government was to refuse consistently to give more money for housing aged persons?

- My attention has been drawn to the statement referred to by the honourable senator. I must say that it gives a very false impression. Housing for aged persons is provided in two different ways one of which is, as honourable senators know, through finance provided under the Aged Persons Homes Act. In that way money is made available to church and charitable bodies which provide homes for aged persons, as a subsidy on the basis of $2 for $1. The second method of making money available is under the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement. The State governments obtain by this the money to use for housing and this can include housing aged persons. I think the honourable senator said that the statement contained the words 'no money had been made available'. I think it is worth while to note the amount of money made available through aged persons homes legislation. This year to the end of March $570,208 has been provided. This provides an interesting comparison with the provision of $316,013 for 1967-68. Honourable senators will note that the amount made available to the end of March this year is an increase on the amount made available for the whole of the previous year. This work is of tremendous importance and I am glad to be able to give the Senate the information I have given.

- My question, which I address to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry, refers to a statement made by the Minister for Trade and Industry, on 17th April, announcing the impending arrival in Australia of Mr Haak, the South African Minister for Economic Affairs. Apparently he is coming to this country to discuss the possibilities of increased trade between South Africa and Australia. In view of the attitude of many important Asian trading partners of Australia towards South Africa and their own refusal to have dealings with the South African Government, will the Minister consider the damage which may result to Australia's trade with Asian countries were it to enter into extensive trading arrangements with South Africa?

- I am not clear from the honourable senator's question whether he is advocating that we should not trade with South Africa. I think his question could be better answered if he put that on the line. We are a trading nation. We will live or wither on the vine in terms of our trading. The facts of life are that we trade with Asian nations; we are grateful for their trade, and they are grateful for ours. When politics get confused with the very lifeblood of a country, I think it is time one took another look at one's politics.

- Will the Minister representing the Postmaster-General obtain from the Postmaster-General a statement setting out times that the telecasts of the swearing-in ceremony of His Excellency the Governor-General in the Senate yesterday were shown in the various States? If the telecast was not relayed direct to each State other than Western Australia, could an explanation be given of why a direct telecast was not made to those particular States?

- We witnessed yesterday in the Senate a most impressive and wonderful ceremony. I feel that it is of great importance that as many people as can see that ceremony through the advantage of television films should do so. I will discuss with the Postmaster-General the points raised by the honourable senator and get an answer for him.

- I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Did Australia make a strong protest to the Indonesian Government against the invasion by armed Indonesian personnel of the Territory of New Guinea in pursuit of West Irians who had crossed into New Guinea?
- It is my understanding that Mr Freeth had a discussion with Mr Malik, 'the Indonesian Foreign Minister, over the incident. Mr Malik indicated that-
- Did we make a strong protest?
- The honourable senator is playing with words. Mr Freeth discussed the matter with Mr Malik. That is what one would expect Foreign Ministers ot

speech.para: Ministers for External Affairs to do. My understanding of the Press statement that was made by Mr Freeth on his return is that Mr Malik indicated that he agreed that the incident should not have 'happened and he agreed that he would take action to see that such an incident did not happen again.

talk.start.para: - Did we make a strong protest?
- If that is not a strong protest, I suggest that the honourable senator sit down and give me half a page on what he means by 'a strong protest'.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Food Standards Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council made any recommendations in relation to the protection of consumers from the presence of excess moisture in frozen poultry? If so, what was that recommendation, and is any action being taken as a result of the recommendation to protect consumers in the Territories of the Commonwealth?
- I was aware of the honourable senator's interest in this matter. I have the following information concerning it from the Minister for Health:

quote.para: The protection of consumers from the presence of excess moisture in frozen poultry has been under consideration for some time by the Food Standards Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. This matter was the subject of a recommendation to the Health and Medical Research Council by the Committee at a meeting held yesterday, 30th April 1969. The recommendation will be considered by the Council at its meeting in October. The matter will be considered by my Department, so far as legislation for the internal Territories is concerned, when the Council's recommendation becomes available.

talk.start.para: - Has the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry seen reports that an American buyer has purchased the Granite Peak sheep station in Western Australia, which is one of the largest sheep stations in that State, consisting of an area of about 860,000 acres? As this would appear to be a classic example of what the Minister for Trade and Industry himself referred to as selling a bit of the farm each year', does the Minister have any comment to make on the purchase of this Australian sheep station by an American buyer?

- I have not seen the report to which the honourable senator refers. For that reason, it would be very unwise for me to make a comment. I am sure that he would appreciate that. Lest he think that I am running away from him on the matter, let me say this: I well recall that American interests went into primary producing areas of Queensland and gave a stimulus which they lacked. I am quite certain that the Minister for Trade and Industry or the Government can be relied upon to see to it that Australia's overall interests are always preserved. If the organisation concerned in this instance intends to go into an area and, by using overseas capital, to develop the area to a degree or capacity far beyond-
- A sheep station.

- Even the honourable senator and I, who are perhaps city slickers, know that there are good sheep stations and bad sheep stations. I think there are good farmers and bad farmers, just as there are good politicians and bad politicians. I acknowledge that I am talking hypothetically. It may well be that the acquisition of a huge area of 860,000 acres which could be brought into high productivity will be a wonderful investment for the region and for the country.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Postmaster-General. As the tempo of modern business requires the utmost expedition in delivery of mails and as there has been in many instances a degree of retrogression in the lapse of time between posting and receipt of mail matter, what steps are being taken to overcome this situation?

- I have had other questions directed to me on this matter. I have a reply to be supplied today to a similar question from Senator Greenwood. I suggest that Senator Laucke might find in that answer an answer to his question. If this is not so, I shall be pleased to put any further suggestions before the Postmaster-General.

- Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that some 2,000 age pensioner residents of the Wyong area of New South Wales are registered for Hong Kong influenza vaccine injections? When can Wyong doctors and chemists expect a delivery of vaccine? They have had very little up to date and this is very largely an age pensioner community.

- It will be recalled that I have replied to a number of questions concerning the doses available. I have informed the Senate of the continuing production of serum at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. The honourable senator's question concerns a particular area and a particular group of people. 1 know that it is the wish of the Minister for Health and, indeed, of the Government that such people should receive their injections as soon as possible. I shall take up the point raised and endeavour to find whether the position can be improved, and I shall let the honourable senator know.

- I direct a question to the Minister for Works. What part, if any, will the Department of Works play in the construction of the $750,000 Cressy Longford irrigation scheme, which has been welcomed by those Liberals who have consistently urged the scheme and has been received by the Tasmanian Labor Minister for Lands and Works with the published statement that he found the grant to this area of Tasmania disappointing?

- It will be recalled that the Minister for National Development announced a grant to Tasmania of $750,000 for the construction of the Cressy water scheme. This was an advance of $750,000 out of a total cost of $840,000, a proportion which is unusually generous today. Items in the New South Wales programme are assisted to the extent of only about 40%. In reply to the specific question, the procedure is that the Commonwealth Government investigates the design and economic potential of the programme and then decides to make a grant to the State Government. The actual execution of the work with that money is a matter for the State and it would be a most unusual arrangement - hitherto not requested - for the State to ask the Commonwealth Department of Works to execute the work. So far as I know, the intention is that the State Public Works Department will carry out the work.

- Can the Minister representing the Minister for National Development advise the Senate who was the official convener of the recent northern development conference held in Western Australia? Can he inform the Parliament whether an invitation was extended to the Queensland Government and, if it was, to whom the invitation was addressed? Did any member of the Queensland Government attend the conference?

- I know that recently there was a meeting of Ministers in the northern part of Western Australia and that it was attended by the Minister for National Development, one other Commonwealth Minister and Ministers from Western Australia. However, I do not know whether a representative of the Queensland Government attended or, if one did attend, who it was. I shall obtain the information for the honourable senator and send it to him in the form of a letter.
- Today?
- Yes, today.

- Does the Minister for Works expect that his Department will play any part in the development of the joint Australian-United States of America defence complex at Woomera in South Australia? If so, what part? Can he indicate whether it is proposed to erect any associated works in places in South Australia other than at Woomera?

- Designs and specifications of the proposed work have not been developed. Although it would be the usual practice for the Department of Works to be called upon in relation to any appropriate part of such establishments, that has not yet been decided. As to associated works, the honourable senator will know that at present the Department of Works is engaged upon an urgent programme of house construction in Alice Springs.

- in addressing my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Transport I refer to the Government's about face in deciding to buy rather than charter two container ships for Australia's overseas shipping line. ls it a fact that the main reason for the change in policy is the crewing problem, a factor which should have been known to Australian negotiators before this extraordinary bungle took place? Will the Minister ask his colleague to furnish a full statement for the Senate explaining the sudden change in a major policy decision? Will that statement deal with matters such as the suggestion that the decision to buy the vessels will eventually cost Australia up to $30m and not the $9m which has been mentioned by the Government? Will it inform us whether it is true that the second ship will cost 47% more than the first vessel, merely because of a different superstructure on the second ship?
- It is a fact that the Commonwealth Government has decided to purchase vessels rather than charter them for a number of years and then buy them.

speech.para: I shall place the honourable senator's specific questions before the Minister for Shipping and Transport and obtain an answer for him.

talk.start.para: - My question is directed to the Minister for Works. Does his Department have control over the construction of buildings and other capital works in the State universities where the finance for such capital works is provided on the recommendation of the Australian Universities Commission and is supplied in part by the Commonwealth and in part by the States? If so, what is the justification for the practice?

- The honourable senator refers in his question to the construction of university buildings with the aid of finance that is allotted by this Government on the recommendation of the Universities Commission - that is to say, capital expenditure that goes towards the building of universities. The practice there is for State public works constructing authorities to carry out the work under the direction of the State Government. There has not been to my knowledge any instance where the Federal Department of Works has been asked to carry out such construction.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration. Notwithstanding the decision announced by the Minister for Immigration that in future details of country of origin will be deleted from Australian citizenship certificates, am I right in assuming that an applicant will still have to indicate the country of origin on his initial application for citizenship?
- I shall be happy to obtain the detailed information required by the honourable senator from the Minister for Immigration.

subdebateinfo.title: LAW REFORM IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

talk.start.para: - In addressing a question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General I refer to his answer given a little earlier in the day. May we take it from what the Minister said that no suggestions have been made in the Senate about law reform in the Australian Capital Territory, by myself in particular? May we take it that the Minister has failed to bring to the attention of the Attorney-General proposals which have been made in this place? As one example, I refer in particular to the suggestion made on 28th November last that during 1969 if the Attorney-General's Department could solve its apparently insoluble problem of staff and so on some attention might be paid to matters such as trial by jury in civil cases in the Australian Capital Territory.
- I wish to say quite firmly that the framework of the question of the Leader of the Opposition represents a complete distortion of anything that has been said here. What I said before in the

speech.para: Senate was that the Leader of the Opposition and all his colleagues had failed to bring before the Senate any proposal to amend the compensation ordinance with relation to compulsory insurance for industrial accidents. It is a complete distortion to say or represent that the Attorney-General has not considered matters of law reform and in particular those matters to which the honourable senator referred. Both the Attorney-General in another place, and I in this place, on his behalf, have referred from time to time to the continuous attention given by the Attorney-General to law reform in the Australian Capital Territory. I have enumerated within the last few months the important fields of law in which reform has been quite substantially advanced.

subdebate.1.para: (Question No. 704)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry, upon notice:

item.para: Has the Minister seen an article in the 'Financial Review' where it is reported that a consulting survey suggests that the cost of operating a container service between England and Australia could be 40 per cent less than the costs of conventional methods of shipping?
Have the consortia, Overseas Containers Ltd. and Associated Container Transport, given any indication as to whether freight rates will be reduced when containerisation is introducednext year?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Trade and Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: Indications are that container shipping operations can lead to considerable cost savings. It should also be realised that the consortia are investing large sums of money in the establishment of these services. So although operating costs should be reduced, capital costs will be increased and these two items will have to be balanced against each other before any cost reductions can flow on to shippers. It can be said, however, the long-term effect on these systems will be to Australia's advantage.

The consortia have consulted with individual exporters on freight rates for this service. The basic sea-leg rates will be the same for both conventional and container ships, but there will be savings in total transport costs for shippers using containers, especially if full container loads are employed. The container consortia estimated savings amount to an average of 7%, depending on the commodity involved and the container transport system used.

subdebate.1.para: (Question No. 804)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry, upon notice:

speech.para: Is there any possibility that urea being produced in Australia will be able to compete with the imported product without the protection of a high tariff, the landed price being $39 a ton and the cost to the farmer being $73.50 a ton?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Trade and Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

speech.para: In Western Australia, the State into which major imports of ureaare occurring, the current landed price for imports of urea is $68.52 per ton. This import price does not include any charges for handling, storage and distribution or any subsidy. Current selling prices of urea after deduction of subsidy in major States are as follows:
New South Wales, $68.70 per ton; Victoria, $77.70 perton; Western Australia, $63.50 per ton; Queensland, $69.20 per ton.

The assistance accorded the Australian production of urea is not by means of a protective duty but by a bounty payable at the rate of $16 per ton. This protective bounty is not to be confused with the subsidy paid to reduce the cost of nitrogenous fertilisers to the farmer which is at the rate of about $36.80 perton of urea.

debate.para: Report of the Public Accounts Committee

talk.start.para: - As Vice Chairman, I present the one hundred and seventh report of the Public Accounts Committee, which relates to subscriber trunk dialling facilities. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a short statement.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Drake-Brockman) - There being no objection, leave is granted.

talk.start.para: - Honourable senators will recall that in the one hundred and fifth report, which was presented on 20th March, your Committee stated that as part of its inquiry into the report of the Auditor-General for the financial year 1967-68 it had examined subscriber trunk dialling facilities. Because of the importance of that matter, however, your Committee decided to report separately upon it.

speech.para: The evidence taken on this matter shows that since 1 959 the Government has adopted a telephone policy framed on a long term basis to meet the expansion of Australia and to confer progressively the benefits of new and improved techniques and modern equipment on the users of telephone services. A basic feature of that policy has been the provision of. facilities which will enable nation-wide subscriber-to-subscriber dialling. The evidence indicated that considerable progress had been made in the development of these facilities by 1968.

Prior to the introduction of STD in 1962 it was recognised during interdepartmental discussions that the availability of these facilities would offer scope for their un authorised use in Commonwealth departments. It had also been recognised, however, that if Commonwealth departments were not prepared to use STD facilities because of their possible misuse, the confidence of business and private subscribers in these facilities could be undermined.It was therefore decided, as a general principle, that access to trunk dialling equipment from Commonwealth department services should not be restricted. At the same time the Postmaster-General's Department was prepared to apply restrictive devices to any subscriber services when specifically requested to do so.

Although STD was introduced in 1962 it was not until 1967 that the Department of the Treasury issued a circular to all departments informing them that while all reasonable precautions must be taken to prevent unauthorised and wasteful use of telephones, there should be no unnecessary impairment of their full and proper use for the performance of public business. Your Committee believes that a useful purpose . would have been served if such a circular had been issued immediately prior to the introduction of STD in 1962.

In 1967-68 the Auditor-General's Department reached the conclusion that substantial misuse of telephone facilities could occur in departments and in June 1968 it suggested to the Department of the Treasury that an interdepartmental committee should be established to evolve a model set of instructions relating to the control of STD. The Treasury proceeded to arrange for the establishment of such a committee and also requested departments to attempt an analysis of their telephone accounts to enable the isolation of the factors that had contributed to increased financial allocations for telephone purposes.

The evidence taken by your Committee from the departments which it examined revealed significant differences in office instructions relating to the control of telephone facilities. In particular, there was no evidence to suggest that departments apply controls through supervision of the private use of telephones for local calls or the use of telephones before or after normal working hours or during lunch-time recesses. The improper use of telephones in any of these circumstances can, however, prove costly.

In view of the differences in departmental practice that were discovered, and the wider based differences discovered by the audit review in 1967-68, your Committee believes that a full scale review of departmental instructions and practices should be undertaken by the interdepartmental committee and that the committee should then evolve a model set of instructions relating to the control of telephone facilities, including STD, for the guidance of departments.

The evidence taken by your Committee also highlighted the problems of telephone cost control that arise in buildings occupied by two or more departments. We believe that these problems, which have evidently been accentuated following the introduction of STD, should be given close attention by the interdepartmental committee. I commend the report to honourable senators and move that it be printed.
Ordered that the report be printed.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 29th April (vide page 1039), on motion by Senator Wright:

quote.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Senator DameIVY WEDGWOOD (Victoria) [12.16] - It is not my intention to delay the passage of this legislation by a lengthy speech in general terms on education. It is very tempting when speaking on such a subject to digress. Already other honourable senators have succumbed to that temptation. As Senator Cohen, who led in this debate for the Opposition, Senator McClelland of the Opposition and Senator

McManus of the Australian Democratic Labour Party have already informed the Senate that they see no objection to the legislation, it appears that the sooner it becomes operative the better. Senator Wright, who represents the Minister for Education and Science (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in this chamber, has said that the main purpose of the Bill is to provide a legislative basis for the five major scholarship schemes under which the Commonwealth Government makes awards to students in schools, technical colleges, colleges of advanced education, universities and similar institutions. He has also informed us that up to the present the technical and secondary scholarship schemes are being handled on an administrative basis under ministerial direction. Post graduate awards, university scholarships and advanced education scholarships are covered under Commonwealth scholarships and awards regulations drawn up under the Education Act.

The Bill repeals the Education Act 1945- 66 and therefore formally abolishes the Commonwealth Office of Education and the Commonwealth Scholarships Board. All honourable senators will remember that the Department of Education and Science was established at the end of 1966. The present Prime Minister, the right honourable J. G. Gorton, became the first Minister for Education and Science in the history of the Commonwealth. We have been told that most of the functions of the former education section of the Prime Minister's Department, which included the Commonwealth Office of Education, were taken over by the new Department, and that the proposed legislation merely formalises arrangements that have been applied in practice ever since the Department of Education and Science was established.

I have some knowledge of the workings of the former Commonwealth Office of Education because, some years ago, the Public Accounts Committee conducted a very extensive examination of the functions and work of that body. We have also been told that the Commonwealth Scholarships Board has continued to function with responsibility with respect only to tertiary schemes of scholarship, but that under this Bill the Minister will be responsible for all schemes subject to the requirements of the Act and the regulations. 1 am sure that all honourable senators will concur with the Minister in his acknowledgment of the services of the Commonwealth Scholarships Board. We welcome his statement that he is examining what arrangements may be made so that the Government may continue to receive advice on specific matters affecting assistance to students.

From my own knowledge the Commonwealth Scholarships Board has performed for many years a very worth while service. lt will be gratifying to many people if the Minister is able to make continuing use of those services in some way. As I said at the outset of my speech, it would be easy to roam all over the whole field of education but, in my opinion, the Bill is specific and therefore in what I have to say I would like to limit my remarks to the five scholarship schemes listed by the Minister in his second reading speech. These schemes are: Firstly, post graduate awards; secondly, university scholarships; thirdly, advanced education scholarships: fourthly, technical scholarships; and fifthly, secondary scholarships. 1 wish to refer briefly to each scheme. I have felt that as the debate has proceeded in this chamber there has been a misapprehension in some quarters as to the schemes and the benefits conferred under them. I wish to set out briefly the advantages that flow to students and parents alike in many cases as a result of these schemes. Post graduate awards provide assistance for post graduate students at Australian universities, usually to a master's degree or a doctor's degree. These are most valuable to students who are able to take advantage of them because, in addition to quite generous allowances, the students also receive a stipend which enables them to pursue post graduate studies without undue hardship.

The Commonwealth universities scholarship scheme provides for awards for full time and part time first degree and diploma courses at Australian universities. During the debate the three types of scholarships have been mentioned. I refer to open entrance scholarships at matriculation, later year scholarships for students who have completed some university studies, and mature age scholarships for students who have turned 25 years of age. Within those three types of award the Commonwealth Government is granting assistance to students at various educational levels. In my opinion it is a most embracing scheme.

J said earlier that it appears from statements that have been made by some honourable senators that they are under a misapprehension, or at least there is some confusion in their minds, particularly with regard to a means test in respect of scholarships. I remind honourable senators of the facts of the scheme. The Commonwealth university scholarships scheme includes the payment of all compulsory fees for all award holders without a means test, lt is true that there is a means test on the living allowances. In 1969 the maximum living allowances are $559 for a student living at home and $904.80 for a student living away from home. If 1 interpreted correctly the opinion of some of the honourable senators who have preceded me in this debate, they believed that the scholarships were all subject to a means test. They were making the point that students were unable to accept scholarships or parents were compelled to deny their children the opportunity to take up scholarships because of an overriding means test. Therefore 1 repeat that the means rest is only in relation to the living allowance and that there is no means test whatsoever in respect of compulsory fees.

talk.start.para: - That can be very important, to a medical student who is 23 or 24 years of age and still has to be kept like a child.

- 1 am not disputing the fact that it may be important. What I am saying is that the statement that these scholarships are all subject to a means test - that statement was made in respect of the whole range of scholarships - just is not true.
- The scholarships are subject to a means test, but one phase of them is not.

- I agree. I am not disputing the fact - I will refer to this later - that parents and students have to work to enable students to stay at universities to complete their courses. But at the moment I am dealing with statements made by Opposition senators in which they claimed that the awards themselves were subject to a means test.

subdebate.1.para: Let me deal now with advanced education scholarships. These are awards for full time and part time study in diploma and other approved tertiary courses at technical colleges and similar institutions. Two kinds of scholarships are available - open entrance scholarships for students at matriculation level and later year scholarships for students who have completed part of an approved course. Here again the benefits are the same as those paid under the university scholarships scheme. In other words, compulsory tuition fees for advanced education are not subject to a means test.

Technical scholarships provide awards mainly for certificate level courses at technical institutions. Substantial benefits arc available to a full time technical scholarship holder and also to a part time technical scholarship holder. The living allowance is $200 a year; there is a textbook and equip ment allowance of $50 a year; and there is a benefit of up to $150 a year for compulsory tuition fees, examination fees and service fees on production of receipts. A part time student holding a technical scholarship receives! an allowance of $100 a year and reimbursement of compulsory fees up to $100 a year.

I come now to secondary scholarships. These are awarded for the final 2 years of secondary schooling. ] have heard only praise for the assistance given to parents through this scheme. The benefits available to a secondary scholarship holder include a living allowance of $200 a year, a textbook and equipment allowance of $50 a year and up to $150 a year for compulsory tuition fees, examination fees and service fees, on production of receipts.

These are very substantial allowances in respect of the education of children, lt is true that everybody with any interest in education, particularly for children, would wish at all times that the utmost assistance be given to every child. But I do not believe that because we feel that way we should let our emotion run away with us to the extent that we see no good in what is already being done. 1 remind the Senate that all these schemes have been introduced by the present Liberal-Country Party Government.

talk.start.para: - Who started them?
- Noone can dispute that all these schemes have been introduced by this Government. This is something that can never be taken away from it.
- But they have been introduced very much too late, don't you think?

- I am not one of those persons - I hope the honourable senator is not either - who try to destroy everything good that is being done by complaining that it is done too late. If these things were done too late, the Labor Party was in government before we were, so why did not it do them then?
- What about after 1949?

- The honourable senator is the one who is complaining. I have not sought to make comparisons between what is happening now and what happened years ago. The honourable senator is the one who is talking about things being done too late. If they have been done too late, his Party was responsible before we acepted responsibility.
- I think Senator Cohen means that it is so long since the Labor Party was in office that its members cannot recall what was done.

- And it will be so long before the Labor Party gets back into office that even Senator Cohen's memory will be very much dimmed by that time. Now let me give the numbers of awards in 1969. I believe that they are impressive no matter what anyone says. They were: Post graduate awards, 650; university scholarship awards, 9,500; advanced education scholarships, 1,500; secondary scholarships, 10,000; and technical scholarships, 2,500; a total 24,150.

subdebate.1.para: When we add to that the estimated number of scholarship holders in training, which includes students who are .undertaking the second and third years of their courses, the number is 56,500. Therefore at the present time 56,500 students are having the advantage of the various scholarship schemes that are in operation. This is something that should, admittedly, encourage us to do more but at the same time we are entitled to feel proud of what has been achieved up to date.

The extent to which the Commonwealth Government is providing direct assistance to these students can be gauged by some figures that were given in a ministerial statement recently. As recently as 1963-64 the Commonwealth was spending $67. 5m on education. The comparable figure for 1968- 69, five years later, is estimated to be $21 0.5m. This is a great increase in expenditure in 5 years. Another interesting comparison shows that whereas 10 years ago 22% of young people in the 15 to 18 years age group - Senator Cohen would be most interested in these children - were at school or were engaged in some other kind of full time education. By 1967 the percentage had risen to 38%, and it is higher today.

The Minister for Education and Science reported very recently that in our schools at the present time there are approximately 300,000 pupils who are above the age of compulsory attendance. This compares with 100,000 ten years ago. It is not a gradual increase. It is a particularly rapid increase in the number of children who are being maintained at school after the age of compulsory attendance.

I was also very interested to read that out of every 100,000 of our population there are 200 graduates at the present time from universities and other tertiary institutions. Ten years ago we were getting only 100 graduates for every 100,000 of the population. This indicates the great advantage not only to students who have an opportunity to do a university or other tertiary course but also to the nation as a whole. So we have to look at education in a broad way as it affects the individual and also as it affects the whole nation.

I should like to deal very briefly with clauses 5 to 9 of the Bill, because these outline the kinds of scholarships and the institutions in which they may be held. The decision to include notification in the Commonwealth Gazette of the approved institutions should satisfy most of the objections that were raised when the legislation was before the Senate in 1967.

The Minister in his second reading speech, following what had been stated by the Minister in another place, adverted to the question of ministerial responsibility and the discretion necessary to avoid what the Minister termed 'unreasonable treatment* and 'possible hardship*. This is appreciated and understood, but Senator Prowse - I thought very rightly - referred to the lack of information as to the form or the intention of the regulations. I know that it is not possible for the Senate to be informed now precisely of the. form or intention of the regulations and I for one shall be awaiting them with interest. We, of course, arc well aware of the fact that there is one safeguard with regard to regulations - this point was taken last night - because ali such regulations come under the scrutiny of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee and it is within the power of the Senate to accept or reject regulations when they come before us. New ground is provided in the Bill for parliamentary scrutiny of the working out of the legislation by the provision for the presentation of an annual report to the Parliament. This. I think, is a very good feature of the Bill. I, with many others in the Senate, will look forward to the report of the Minister and we will be able then to follow better what is being done in relation to the Act.

In conclusion, I should' like to commend the Government on' its interest in and assistance to education generally. I support the Bill, which replaces' what has evidently been a very loose working arrangement with what has been termed a 'legislative framework' within which the schemes may operate. I would not agree with anyone who tries to put forward the argument that the Commonwealth Government is lacking in its support for education generally or that it has been niggardly in its approach specifically. Within the powers conferred upon it under the Constitution, the Government has made increasing grants in many ways to education, but in my opinion none is more valuable than the one in which we seek to assist students to obtain a better education. In this, as I said earlier, we are helping not only the child but also the parents. I know of many,, many parents who are making tremendous sacrifices to ensure that their children obtain a better education than they themselves were able to acquire. So, Sir, I commend the Government on what it has done in the past. I believe that there is a need for assistance and that the demand , will increase. I also believe that this Government will make available increasing amounts of money , for assistance to education in a variety of ways. I regret that on many occasions instead of being given some credit for what has been done the Government is assailed, in my opinion, very unfairly.
