talk.start.para: - I ask for leave to make a personal explanation.
- There being no objection, leave is granted.

- When this Bill was being debated by the Senate on 23rd April, in the course of my speech, as reported at page 1007 of Hansard, I gave some figures which I then believed to represent the percentage of scholarships offered to applications received in the technical college sphere. I find that 1 had insufficiently appreciated the document from which I was reading and that what I. was stating on that occasion was the percentage of the total number of scholarships which were awarded in each State. To make matters worse I indicated that the source of my information was the Legislative Research Service of the Library. I regret that this inaccurate information should have been given to the Senate. I am indebted to the Legislative Research Service for the correct figures. Scholarships offered, as a percentage of applications received, were as follows: In New South Wales, 23.8%; in Victoria, 28.1%; in Queensland, 22.3%; in South Australia, 32.8%; in Western Australia, 16.2%; and in Tasmania, 60.9%. I would appreciate it if those figures were now regarded as being substituted for those which I gave inadvertently in error on 23rd April.

- The Bill before us brings forcibly to . the Senate and to the Australian public generally the manner in which the Menzies, Holt and Gorton-McEwen Administrations have pursued and are pursuing the very important social advances in this Commonwealth. In particular the Bill highlights the advancement in educational assistance provided for students in a number of fields. We must congratulate the Government on the excellent manner in which it has sought to improve educational standards in Australia. Indeed, over the past 5, 10 or 15 years one has been able to sense a change in the attitude of people throughout the community in their recognition of the great importance of education in this country and in this country's future. I consider that it is of immense importance that we maintain high standards of education in the community and also maintain Australia's standing in the world. There are nations of much greater population than ours in areas quite near to our shores. Only by having an advanced society in Australia will we be able to take proper advantage of the great assets that we have and be able to use them effectively.

speech.para: The Bill deals with the important matter of allocating scholarships in five areas. It applies to scholarships for post-graduate students, to scholarships for university training and for advanced education, and it relates also to technical scholarships and secondary scholarships. As to the amount of money involved, next year $35m will be required to cover the expense of that which is proposed in the Bill. Not one member of the Senate objects to this measure. 1 regard that as a recognition of its importance and acceptance. The matter of finance for education is one of the most important and controversial questions in Australia today. The Federal Government has been able to develop its activities in education because in Australia we have now quite a sizeable income from taxation which can be applied in this area. I have no doubt that if it had been suggested some years ago that in 1969 the Federal Government would be spending so many millions of dollars in the various fields of education there would have been great arguments to show that the amount could not be found.

It should be mentioned that there is some disquiet in the minds of members of State governments about the manner in which the Federal Government is entering the field of education, but it must be remembered that already we have a Department of Education and Science under the leadership of a well qualified Minister who is leading his Department very ably. It is considered in many places that the Federal Government's activities in education are an interference in State government affairs. I think no-one would deny that.

talk.start.para: - Under section 96 of the Constitution the Parliament has power to grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit.
- I appreciate the comments made by the honourable senator. I hope they have some relevance to what we are talking about.
- You should try to emulate his example.

- I do not doubt that in Senator Marriott's State, as well as in mine, there is disquiet about the manner in which the Federal Government is entering the field of educational assistance. The disquiet exists not only among members of Parliament, both government and opposition, but is evident also among some members of the community. Does any honourable senator deny that? I do not suggest that the attitude is detrimental to education throughout Australia, but there are some people who have their own view as to the manner in which education should be maintained as a State responsibility. Certainly areas of previous responsibility in education in the States are being eroded by the manner in which the Commonwealth Government is going about its work. The influence which the Federal Government has in relation to university management is something which must be considered today.

speech.para: If I may revert to my reference to finance, I was anxious to mention the great effort made by the State Government in Victoria in providing its financial allocation for education. It is a wonderful effort in a most important area. In 1967-68 the Victorian Government spent more than 30% of its total budget on education by providing $240,134,254 in that field. Perhaps Senator Cormack will correct me if I have not stated the percentage correctly.

talk.start.para: - it is nearly 50% in New South Wales.

- These are enormous amounts to be expended by the States in just one field of tertiary education. I had been referring to the attitude some people are taking to possible interference by the Federal authorities in the administration of not the educational systems including the universities. In this connection, I was most interested in a statement made by Professor Hills last week at a meeting at which the question of university relations with science and industry overseas and in Australia was discussed. Amongst the points which he made, this one in particular was marked by me: - Policies are rapidly being established by the Ministry ot Science and Education in relation to technical colleges and the identification of priorities for research. These will have marked effect on us very shortly.

speech.para: The universities may well find that they will be forced to adopt new attitudes and 1 make no excuse for using the word 'forced'. 1 quote the kind of direction by the AUC thai has already caused us to cut down rapidly on >ingle subject student enrolments, to move towards the abolition of sub-graduate diplomas and to rigidly control our total enrolments.

This is a man whose opinion 1 have heard quoted over a number of years and 1 believe that the point he makes here is well taken. Perhaps he has more knowledge of this matter than I have. He went on to say:

quote.para: In former years we might have debated these questions and made our own decisions but we now work within the ambits and policies laid clown by other authorities and enforced by the power of the dollar.

speech.para: Whilst recognising the importance of what is taking place in the educational field under the auspices of the Federal Government, [ make the point that all authorities must give sympathetic consideration to what the projected ideas of the Federal authority will be.

talk.start.para: - In what way do you suggest force is influencing the course you mention?

- I take it thai the point, made by the professor was that in actual fact the Australian Universities Commission had issued some direction which had forced- a° cut down. I quoted what the Professor had said. 1 can only assume that what he said was correct. If it was not correct, then it would be as well if ' the Commonwealth authority made some comment about the matter. The address to which 1 have referred was published in all the Victorian newspapers last week. 1 understand it was published in the 'Australian' last Thursday. I believe that there might be some directions in which the universities are not being left with all the authority that they would wish to have. 1 have already said that I acknowledge the wonderful work being done by the Federal authorities. I do not say that complete autonomy need rest with the universities. In fact, when it comes to the management of finance; I feel that what the Federal authorities may do with the force of the dollar may be very much to the benefit of the universities. But I have pointed out that in the minds of the State Governments, in the mind of the general public and in the minds of some academic people there is some doubt as to the influence that the new department might have on their particular areas of management.
- The State governments do not have to take this help, you know.
- 1 agree, but I do not think that would mean very much to the South Australian Government or the Victorian Government. 1 feel that they are going to be most, anxious to get this money.
- Would you mind stating in what field the professor said they are being forced to adopt certain attitudes?
- In the first place, the professor used the words 'technical colleges'. He then went on to say:

quote.para: The universities may well find they will be forced lo adopt new attitudes and 1 make no excuse for using the word 'forced'. I quote the kind of direction by the AUC that has already caused us to cm down rapidly on single subject student enrolments, to move towards the abolition of sub-grade diplomas, and to rigidly control our total enrolments.

speech.para: Let me point out here that I have endeavoured to have sent to me an exact copy of the professor's speech, lt was taken on tape and then transcribed from the tape. 1 can only hope that the words I quoted are the exact words used by the professor. But I think the point he was making is quite clear. The Minister might care to comment on this matter later. I believe that as we progress with Commonwealth aid in the field of university education we undoubtedly will conflict with the wishes of certain individuals throughout universities and other educational institutions.

One point that I do wish to discuss relates to assistance by Federal authorities to students who in the mind of the public, are to all intents arid purposes spending too much of their time in ways other than those calculated to give them most benefit from the particular scholarship which they have been awarded.' J refer to certain activities of students which have been under discussion from lime to time and the attitude adopted by certain students within the various colleges. One thing I should like to discuss is the need for the authorities to take adequate safeguards with relation to the use of drugs by students of universities and other educational institutions. One important factor that we must continually bear in mind is that we must be prepared to provide finance in future for the enormous growth that is likely to take place in the number of students who will be attending universities. As yet I have not become aware of any statement made by the Commonwealth Ministry which would indicate that it recognises that there is to be an enormous growth in the number of students attending universities. I realise that we are aware that many more students are going to flow into the universities, our colleges of advanced education and like institutions, but one thing that has struck me very forcibly is the great problem that besets the management of universities in the development of their various facilities on a particular campus.

As honourable senators know. I was recently overseas attending a conference of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. Whilst overseas, 1 visited Canada where I spoke to a gentleman who was adviser to the Vice-Chancellor of one large university in Canada. He mentioned several points which have remained firmly in my mind. He told me that at his university the enrolment 5 years ago was 18,000 students. He told me that the authorities at that university planned for a growth in enrolment, but could never has envisaged the tremendous growth which did in fact take place during the 5 year period. He mentioned that the number enrolled increased from 1S.000 to 33,000 in 5 years. What struck me then was the great problem which faces a university even in having to plan for a growth of that kind. I alert our new Commonwealth Ministry to the likelihood of that problem arising here. I believe that from such an enormous growth How many of the problems confronting the students at universities as well as those who administer the institutions. The gentleman who spoke to me had, in his day, held an administrative job in the Navy. He was a retired naval man. He had administered a cadet school of some 6,000 individuals. I can imagine what a tough man he must have been lo control such a college. He said that he had found that they had to give in to student demands although he had thought years ago that this could never happen. He said that the demands of the students had to be met.

talk.start.para: - What university?
- 1 do not know that I should give the name of the university but undoubtedly the numbers I could cite would quickly identify it.
- A university in Canada?

- In Canada. He mentioned then one of the demands made by the students of a particular faculty. They demanded that there should be no final examinations for the granting of a degree. I imagine that this is a subject that has been discussed in the community. I have read on a number , of occasions that it is being proposed, even in this country. The point is that the university agreed that no examination would be required for the granting of a degree in the field of political science because of a decision made by the students.
- Is that not an abdication of the responsibility of the people in control of the universities?

- Now the Minister has made a statement. I hope he will seek authority to apply that principle and use it on every occasion when we have these interruptions to university work such as riots on the campus and demands by students as to what they should do. I could cite a number of other things mentioned to me while I was overseas relating to the demands of students at that college. They demanded that the sexes be able to mix at all times. Recently at a university - it is not in Canada - the showering facilities became freely available for both sexes to use. Such a demand has not yet been voiced in Australia. However, I believe that if the demands by students continue along the lines of those made by students overseas, the Minister's words will have to be applied to the authorities in order that they do not forgo the responsibility placed in their hands.
- Why did the Canadian authorities have to submit to the demands of the students? Was any explanation given?

- The explanation given to me regarding the incidents I have cited was that if they had not submitted or had attempted to use force against the students the university would have been put back as many years as was the Columbia University by the attempt to use force against the students there. That is what I was told.

speech.para: There is a further point which our federal authority may well take into account. In the years that I have been in the Senate the problem of the taking of drugs has been gradually increasing throughout the community. There have been demands by the Opposition and by Government supporters that more severe measures be taken to control drug taking. Perhaps the attempts made to control this habit have been successful; perhaps they have not. We hear of very little drug taking in Australian universities. However, I was told on a visit to the university I have mentioned that a survey Conducted there and at another Canadian university had revealed that over 80% of the students at the two universities had already been on a trip on drugs and that more than one-third of that number were regular drug takers. The word hooked' was used. If is difficult to imagine that this could be the position. However, if what we hear about events overseas is the truth then the federal authority in Australia should take a stand in the matter because of what is likely to happen in Australian universities. This is a most important matter. We should not degrade the very elite of the community by allowing the taking of drugs or the sale of drugs which, apparently, is carried on openly in some universities overseas. I mention these things, Mr Deputy President, because I believe that our Department of Education and Science could perhaps assume a wider roving commission than a degree of interference in the various State, spheres.

I note that under this Bill the Commonwealth Office of Education and the Commonwealth Scholarships Board are both abolished. I note also that there is to be no replacement at present for the Scholarships Board. I suggest it would be wise to see that this matter is attended to fairly shortly. However, I believe the Minister envisages doing so, I well .recall that a similar Bill was before the Senate last year and that the Senate rejected it. We know the reasons why it was. rejected.

I want to draw attention to the very wide discretion which this Bill purports to give to the Minister. I suggest that no Bill that has come before this Parliament has given a Minister such wide discretion in a particular field, lt may be a good thing that there is this wide discretion and 1 do not oppose it. I merely wish to draw the attention of honourable senators to the point 1 make. 1 instance the many times that it has been necessary to state that the Minister will have entire discretion. In clause 5, at line 3, it is stated that 'in accordance with the regulations' a certain thing may be granted by the Minister. In fact, clause 5 states:

quote.para: Scholarships, to be known as Commonwealth Secondary Scholarships, may,- subject to and in accordance wilh (he regulations, be granted by the Minister ... 1 am merely instancing some of the many occasions in this Bill where there is a discretion in the hands of the Minister. At line 5 these words are used: 'at a level approved by the Minister'. At line 8 we read these Words: 'Under a direction of the Minister'. At line 12 the Bill states: 'granted by the Minister'. At line 14 it states: 'any course approved by the Minister'. At line 17 it states: 'under a direction of the Minister'; at line 21 we read: 'be granted by the Minister'; at line 23: 'any course approved by the Minister'; and at line 26: 'under a direction of the Minister'. This Bill provides a very wide discretion for the Minister. As 1 read the Bill it is only in clause 1 8 that it makes clear that the Parliament may know what the Minister has determined. It is very important for us to be aware of the determinations made by the Minister in this very important and controversial field of education so that we will know that there is no discrimination in the States. Clause 18(1.) states:
An approval, direction or determination of the Minister under this Act may be varied or revoked by the Minister.

speech.para: I have not quite come to the point, 1 suppose, because this sub-clause deals with a determination, a direction or revocation by the Minister.

talk.start.para: - Does the honourable senator suggest that the approval, direction or determination should remain in force for all time and should be incapable of variation?
- To understand the full implications of the Bill I would have to read the Minister's second reading speech.
- And properly understand it.
- Yes. Clause 18(2.) states - and this is the core of the point I wish to make:

quote.para: The Minister shall make such arrangements as he thinks proper for giving public notice of the giving or making by him under this Act of any approval, direction or determination or of any variation or revocation by him of such an approval, direction or determination.

speech.para: That sub-section has been worded very loosely. Perhaps that was done for a particular reason, but 1 am not sufficiently informed on clause 18 to say that it enables me to understand fully the reasons for a direction, approval or determination by the Minister, or any variations thereto.

talk.start.para: - The honourable senator is very brave.

- I do not think there is anything particularly brave about mentioning these matters. The Minister for Works (Senator Wright), who is at the table, is very anxious to hear the comments of honourable senators on the Bill. I draw attention to the fact that this Bill is worded very loosely. Parts of it are worded loosely for a very sound reason and I understand why this would be so. I add my great appreciation to .that expressed by other honourable senators for what the Government has done by introducing this Bill. The Government is entering into the field of education and science in a most helpful way. Senator Ormonde will agree with mc that the Bill will be of great advantage to students throughout the Commonwealth and that the work which will be done under the provisions of the Bill could not be done by any State Government. I congratulate the Minister on the Bill.

- The debate on this Bill has been very comprehensive and most interesting. The financial implications of the scholarship scheme have been very clearly and comprehensively indicated by Senator Dame Ivy Wedgwood. I confine my remarks to a few overall observations about scholarship schemes generally. I would say that one of the most pleasant ways in which the Department of Education and Science helps to further the cause of education is in the provision of scholarships. This year some 56,000 students hold scholarships under five Commonwealth schemes. This year 24,150 new scholarships were offered. The significance of these numbers cannot escape the notice of anyone who desires to see an ever-growing opportunity for our youth to receive that educational background which is vital to the person receiving it and to the well-being and the progress of the nation generally. Equality of opportunity in education is afforded to all under our nation's education system. It is good to know that the Government has provided financial assistance to enable talent to come to fruition. Over the years, throughout the nation, students, without the assistance of scholarships, would not have been able to attain their goals or achieve their ambitions. In the process of the education of these students the national welfare has been served admirably because we have had the benefit of talents which otherwise would have remained dormant and to which expression would never have been given. Without a scholarship scheme the individual students would not have been assisted to a higher educational level, and as a result many things which collectively we need in a modern society of well educated people would not have been provided.

speech.para: With the passing of the years the need is growing for better educated people, for people educated in the sense referred to by Senator McManus yesterday when he referred to the quality of education and the fact that people are not necessarily educated in a complex of buildings and impersonal surroundings which lack vitality. What is needed is a real drawing out of the individual's ability to think, to be prepared, to investigate and to look deeply into things. The purpose of education in its broadest sense is to bring out the basic characteristics of the individual and to develop the character of the individual. Education also enables the populace to achieve standards which will ensure better conditions overall.

The Government is providing no Jess than $28.9m this year, or approximately $540,000 per week. This will be of inestimable benefit to students. In 1964-65, $12.7m was provided for scholarship schemes. The increase in the amount provided over the years illustrates the acceptance of the need for scholarship schemes. Without any further changes in the rates or conditions of expen diture, it is expected that the monetary provision will amount to S35m in 1971-72, which would work out at $700,000 each week of the year to be devoted to giving scholarships to the optimum number of students.

I do not think we really appreciate the breadth and the scope of the many avenues of education and learning which are bound up in these scholarship schemes. This growing breadth and scope covers all facets of requirements of a modern society. 1 conclude by paying my humble tribute to the Government for what it has done over the years, through the scholarship schemes, to assist the individual and in the national interest to provide something which will ensure - as I have no :doubt whatever that it will - a better nation for the future. I have pleasure in supporting. this Bill.

talk.start.para: - in reply - I am sure the Minister for Education and Science (Mr .Malcolm Fraser) will be as gratified as I am about the degree of attention that has been given to this Bill, which is one of the Government's contributions towards furthering the cause of education. It is particularly pleasing that the Government should have the support of so many of its colleagues in the Senate who took the time to prepare their speeches and express their individual thoughts on the various facets of education. It could be expected that the parliamentary debate on this subject would be of interest to students and educationalists because the subject of education is a vital issue which is of interest to the community as a. .whole. I am sure that the contributions that have been so thoughtfully made in the Senate will be read with interest.

speech.para: Several speakers on the Government side have referred to some of the general facets of education since the present Federal Government really implemented a policy of expansion of educational assistance. I wish to refer to only two or three aspects generally. In particular it should be noted, as a means of comparison, that over the past 7 years from 1961-62 to the current financial year 1968-69 total Commonwealth financial assistance has risen from $55m to $2 10m. In 1955-56 this expenditure represented 2% of total
Commonwealth expenditure whereas in 1968-69 it is 4% of total Commonwealth expenditure.

Another feature that we all could bear in mind with real interest is the specific increase that has been made in scholarship assistance. In 1961-62 our scholarship assistance amounted to S6m. As my colleagues have said, in the current year it is $29m. I shall refer to that aspect at a later stage of my speech in reply but 1 point out that in 7 years the aggregate amount has grown from $6m to $29m. Then it should be noted that not only is the Federal Government making an increased contribution from its Budget in respect of education but also that the State governments of Australia have increased their aggregate appropriations over the past 10 years from S225m to $646m. When we realise that those increased appropriations by the States have been enabled, in a large measure, by the improved reimbursement grants that have been arranged in relation to income tax revenue, I think all honourable senators will record with satisfaction that all governments in Australia recognise the increasing need for financial assistance in the field of education. That follows from the emphatic initiation and maintenance of policy that emanated from the Menzies Government in the early and mid-1950s.

I want to say one thing in deference to what Senator McManus said in the course pf the debate. He said that he was not very much impressed by a recital of figures showing budgetary appropriations to the cause pf education. I felt that his meaning was that that was not the sole criterion by which the national education effort should be judged. He thoughtfully called attention to the need for constant vigilance in respect of the content of education - what was being taught - and the conditions in which access to education should be made available to every student. It is pertinent to remind ourselves that if there are activities of an untoward nature on the campus which deter or exclude students, or which curtail a field of study which some students wish to undertake, those really are restrictions that have no proper place within a genuine university.

Perhaps it is particularly timely at this time to refer to that matter. Fortunately we have not reached that stage in Australia yet. I should like to incorporate a reference to what has fallen so recently from my colleague, Senator Webster, with regard to the number of students at a Canadian university having increased from 20,000 to 32,000 in the course of a short bracket of years - say 6 or 7 years - that increase in number leading to a changed attitude whereby the government of the university waived a final examination for a degree. I go on record as saying that no government that is worthy of calling itself a government will appropriate money to a weakling university of that kind. Nor does the government of a university that yields to that kind of pressure deserve to exercise the functions of a university government. lt is salutary to remind ourselves that before this grand campaign of educational assistance was entered, upon by the Menzies Government, the Government, as 1 have said in this Senate before with a great deal of pride, took advice from Sir Hugh Murray and interpolated between the political government of the country and the governments of the various universities the Australian Universities Commission. The whole purpose of the Constitution of that Commission was to remove the universities from direct contact with and individual interference by any political government. The Government decided that there would be a commission composed mainly of university people who would represent the general contact with the individual universities and would convey a general recommendation to the political government, thereby removing in a large measure the possibility that political government might interfere unduly with any university. The question as to a final examination for a degree is a peculiar responsibility of the university government and has to be exercised upon a genuine consideration of all factors relevant to education. It should not in the slightest degree be governed by the idea that a number of students on the campus putting forward that view could prevail upon the university government against its will.

talk.start.para: - That is not exactly the way in which I put the proposition.
- That is as I understood it. If it has missed the mark I incorporate that remark out of the deference

speech.para: I have for the honourable senator's comments. Having said that, let me now make one or two references to the debate to which we have listened. The first speaker in the debate was Senator Cohen, who led for the Opposition. It is unfortunate. I think, that the honourable senator, not only in the instance to which he directed our attention on the resumption of the debate after lunch but in various other respects as well, either has failed to quote accurate figures or has quoted them in a sense in which they do not justify the conclusions that he drew from them. I wish to remind the Senate of some of the things that Senator Cohen said in his contribution to the debate. His speech is recorded in Hansard of 23rd April 1969. Senator Cohen put forward the view thai the proportion of successful applicants for university scholarships is decreasing. The honourable senator is trying to give the Senate the impression that because the figures he quoted at page 1006 of Hansard seem to show a decreasing percentage of successful applicants for scholarships, this is something of' real significance.

talk.start.para: - lt means that competition is fierce.

- I do not think that I interjected very much during the honourable senator's speech. My purpose in rising is to try to collate figures in as accurate a way as I can so thai they will be on record and will elucidate the position for the Senate. All I am emphasising at the moment is the invalidity of using figures showing the number of applications for scholarships as a basis upon which to judge the progress of the scholarships scheme. The fact is that because of the increased availability of scholarships generally there has been a tendency over recent years for application statistics to be inflated. Students are also putting in applications for scholarships long before the results of their examinations are known. It is quite obvious that the number of applications for scholarships has no relationship to the question whether the proportion of university entrants who receive scholarships is increasing. In fact, about 25% of the studnets who are offered Commonwealth university scholarships reject them. So, not only are the application statistics inflated, but also we find that 25% of the students who are offered scholarships reject them. These offers are rejected because of, amongst other things, the variety of scholarships that are available today. Students put in application for several types of scholarships and accept the one which best suits them.

speech.para: At page 1006 of Hansard Senator Cohen is also reported as saying that a student offering himself today for a university course has less chance of getting a scholarship than he did in 1952. The honourable senator quoted figures to support his viewpoint. As a matter of fact, in 1952 the number of entrants to bachelor degree courses at Australian universities represented a little less than 5% of the age group for university entrance. In 1968, even taking into account the increased population, the corresponding figure was 11%. The next comment I wish to make relates to the statement by Senator Cohen that he had some difficulty reconciling certain figures. In that respect it would appear that the honourable senator used figures which were given in the other place in February of this year in reply to question No. 595 on the notice paper. Those figures are correctly quoted but they relate specifically to applications for all types of university scholarships - open entrance scholarships, mature age scholarships and later year scholarships - and not merely to open entrance scholarships as the honourable senator stated.

The second set of figures that the honourable senator quoted at page 1007 of Hansard refers specifically to open entrance scholarships, lt appears that the honourable senator had difficulty reconciling those figures, too. I wish to place it on record that the figure of 16.9% relates to open entrance scholarships and the figure of 18.3% relates to all awards. I repeat my earlier statement that the figures the honourable senator has given are doubtful because the whole structure of his statistics is based on the number of applications for scholarships. A more valid basis for considering whether the Government is making progress with its awards is to relate the number of awards to the number of university entrants and not the number of scholarship applicants.

Senator Cohenalso made a comparison between the number of mature agc university scholarships available and the number of applicants for those scholarships. As we have been informed by Senator Dame Ivy Wedgwood, and this fact has since been confirmed, mature age university scholarships are granted only to students who have turned 25 years of age. A comparison between the number of applications and the number of awards is again doubtful. By way of illustration it might be noted that of 1,659 applicants in 1968 for mature agc university scholarships less than 1,000 had obtained sufficiently good results to be considered. lt might also be noted that the number of mature age university awards was increased from 120 in 1968 to 250 in 1969.

Senator Cohenalso referred to a comparison of later year university scholarships. Again, I refer to the fact that statistics on the number of applications are of little value. For example, of nearly 7,000 applicants in 1968 only 5,000 met the minimum academic requirements and of that figure only 2,000 or 40% were successful in gaining awards. Senator Cohen said that opportunities for university scholarships were being eroded. The figures I wish to quote relate not to applications for Commonwealth university scholarships but to the number of Commonwealth university scholarships granted and they exclude higher degree scholarships. In 1 952, shortly after the scheme began. 25% of university students held Commonwealth scholarships. In 1956, the figure was 28%; in 1968 it was still 28%. We should remind ourselves that whereas the 25% in 1952 represented 6,608 university scholarship holders, in 1968 the 28% represented 24,784 scholarship holders.

It is clear that an entirely wrong impression is given by the figures quoted by Senator Cohen in this context. One would be led to believe, in following the use that he made of the statistics, that our actual contribution in the form of university scholarships had withered in that time, whereas we have maintained and improved the percentage of university population - university entrants over the period - from 25% in 1952 to 28% in 1968, and the actual number of scholarship holders in that period from 6,608 to 24,784. That comes from the fact that the population of university entrants has increased much more rapidly than the general population.

I need not refer to the further figures cited by the honourable senator as reported al page 1007 of Hansard, because he himself took the occasion early this afternoon to correct them. At page 1008 Senator Cohen is reported to- have said that he thinks there is a need for a national survey of education matters. We had a debate recently in the Senate on an associated issue and negatived the- view that a general inquiry should be conducted. However, for the satisfaction of honourable senators I advise that the Minister and his Department are in constant consultation with vice-chancellors' committees, national unions of university students, education departments and all education authorities who are constituted in such a way that they meet regularly. What I have said is evidence that a vigilant attitude is maintained by the Federal Department.

Senator Cohen,as he has done on previous occasions, referred to certain figures as a percentage of the gross national product, or the national income, of other countries which he says demonstrate that other countries devote a greater percentage of their national product to education than we do. He instanced, if you please, Venezuela and Iraq, as well as Morocco and Korea. It is entirely fallacious to refer to figures of that sort because the component of the education appropriation in those countries is completely unknown. It is not a valid comparison unless you have a fairly identical subject in each country. We have been unable to confirm, or indeed to find, figures in respect of Venezuela or Iraq, but with regard to Morocco and Korea it should go oh record that so far from their figures being greater than Australia's, they are less.

Senator Cohenwas good enough to treat us to a contention' that we should adjust scholarships according to the cost of living. I suppose most honourable senators know that in the period from 1951 to 1968 the consumer price index rose by 92%. In the same period the maximum living allowances for the two types of scholarships to which they are appropriate - Commonwealth university scholarships and advanced education scholarships - rose by 115% for students living at home, and by- 111 % for students living away from home. So that whereas the consumer price index rose in the period by 92%, the cost of living allowance for the two types of scholarship 1 have named rose in one instance by 115% and in the other instance by 111%. In approximately the same period- from 1951 to 1969- the adjusted family income upon which the living allowance is adjusted has been increased from $800 to $2,500. or an increase of over 300%. Where then is the value in an education debate of suggesting that we have been failing to adjust the advantages and benefits of these scholarships having regard to the known increase in the cost of Jiving? So much for Senator Cohen's contribution.

I will now. without unduly detaining the Senate, refer to the speech of my colleague from Tasmania. Senator Marriott. My colleague urged that we avail ourselves of extensive publicity. I want him to know that many thousands of brochures and application cards are distributed each year to secondary schools and the institutions in which scholarships can be held. Posters are also distributed and advertisements are placed in newspapers at times near to the closing date of applications. These are the efforts we make at the present time to bring to the notice of all students who may be interested the availability of scholarships. I am obliged to my colleague for the reminder that that notwithstanding, some students fail to be notified of the availability of these scholarships. However, it will be some satisfaction to Senator Marriott to be reminded that the Department is conscious of the need for a real effort to publicise the availability of scholarships and to direct its attention to that specific purpose quite consciously and in a sustained manner.

Senator Marriottalso suggested that statistics in the Department's annual report should be related to the financial year, rather than the period ending as soon as possible after December in each year. Annual reports cover the period to December each year so as to coincide with the academic year. All Australian schools and university institutions govern themselves on the basis of an academic year ending at Christmas. Therefore it is most desirable that statistics and other material available in the annual report should be collated on the same basis.

talk.start.para: - 1 move:

quote.para: That so much of standing order 407a be suspended as would prevent Senator Wright speaking in reply for more than 30 minutes.

talk.start.para: - 1 am most obliged to the Senate for its courtesy. 1 come now to a reference to the speech made by Senator Prowse. The particular point of his speech to which I refer is his concern about the expression in the Bill which leaves the courses that qualify for scholarships to be approved by the Minister. The courses are not to be prescribed by regulation. The courses are to be such as are 'approved by the Minister'. In this connection I refer to advanced education scholarships, university scholarships, post-graduate awards, technical scholarships and secondary scholarships in respect of the level of secondary education.

speech.para: I think honourable senators will best understand my approach if I ask them to refer to the annual report of the Commonwealth Scholarships Board for 1967, which is the last one to have been published. Under- the heading 'Approval of Courses* they will see an indication of the past attitude of the Minister. No doubt, that will be subject to no great variation in the future. Under the sub-heading 'Commonwealth University Scholarship Scheme', the first course listed is a diploma course in education at the University of New South Wales. In respect of that the Board reports:

quote.para: A post-graduate Diploma in Education course is available at the University of New South Wales. It is a 1 year full time course of study but it is anticipated it will also be offered later on a part time basis over 2 years. The course is open to graduate students from the University of New South Wales and other approved universities.

speech.para: The next item illustrates the point quite clearly. It is headed 'Diploma in Applied Psychology - University of Newcastle' and reads:

quote.para: A post-graduate Diploma in Applied Psychology was introduced at the University of Newcastle in 1.967 to enable graduates with majors in psychology to gain additional specialisation. Candidates for the diploma are required to complete 1 year of full time and 2 years of part time study. lt is of advantage that I . refer to one or two other items, I hope not too tediously. The third item is headed 'Combined Course : - Bachelor of Commerce/Bachelor of Laws - University of Queensland' and reads:

The combined course Bachelor of Commerce/ Bachelor of Laws is now being offered at the University of Queensland. Under this combination a. student can complete the requirements for bachelor, degrees in both the Faculties of Commerce and Law in 6 years of study (4 years full time arid 2 years part time).

speech.para: Then, reference is made to a combined course in arts and law at the University of Adelaide. I will omit one or two other items and then refer to an interesting one, which is headed 'Diploma in Computer Science - University of Adelaide' and reads:

quote.para: A post-graduate Diploma in Computer Science course is available' at the University of Adelaide.

speech.para: Then reference is made to a combined course for the degrees of Bachelor, of Music and Bachelor of Arts. The eighth item is a post-graduate Diploma in Rural Accounting. I pass from university scholarships to advanced education scholarships. In this section of the report . reference is made to a course for a Diploma of General Science at the Emily Mcpherson College of Domestic Economy, a sub-primary teacher training course at the Dominican Training College, Watson, and other subprimary teacher training courses, as well as other courses.

The reason for this provision in the Bill, under which the approval of courses is left to the Minister, is so that, no doubt always on the advice of the technical officers of his Department, consideration can be given to the content of any of these individual courses that are proposed by universities and other institutions. They vary so much that a decision is required on each one. They concern not postgraduate studies for a master's degree or a Ph.D. degree but studies for bachelor's degrees and diplomas, including postgraduate diplomas but not post-graduate degrees. I suggest that on reflection my colleagues will agree that the instances
I haVe given show that the variety of courses requires individual decisions by the Minister.

I know that the aspect about which Senator Prowse is concerned is that there should not be a subjection pf education to the individual viewpoint pf a political officer - a Minister. We have always to be on our guard against that because it is capable of abuse. But the safeguards here are, firstly, that the course has to be proposed by the university or educational institution; secondly, that in our system of government it is to be expected that the Minister will not act upon his personal or political preconceived ideas but will act with the advice of his education officers; and thirdly - I need not remind honourable senators of this - that he is' always answerable to the most vigilant attention of the members of the Senate. So, in those respects I suggest that, : the Bill having incorporated, as I reminded' the Senate in the second reading speech, the important principles of benefits and conditions of awards in regulations,' the Senate can safely entrust the approval of courses to the Minister in the circumstances to which 1 have referred.

Senator McClellandmade a claim that in the New South Wales Department of Education teacher trainees could manipulate the system - 'manipulate' is the only word appropriate to the process he envisaged - so that they could get more out of using a teacher .training scholarship from that Department and then resigning than they could get out of a Commonwealth scholarship. Of course, the fact is that the teacher trainee student is under bond - usually for 3 . years and maybe up to 5 years - and it -has always to be recognised that one would expect a student who commits himself to an -obligation to serve in an education department for from 3 to 5 years after the completion of his training to get a few dollars more during his training period than one who simply avails himself of a - Commonwealth scholarship and is free to use his education where he will at a later time. I should just like to have it on record that those figures that Senator McClelland gave and which appear on page 1038 of Hansard are now out of date.. For 1969 there are 9,500 university scholarships, comprising 7,500 open entrance scholarships, including 250 mature age awards and 2,000 later awards.

talk.start.para: - How many applications?

- I regret that Senator McClelland was not, I think, in the chamber when I referred to the futility of using applications as a basis. 1 have gone quite fully into the claim that I make that we should relate them to the entrants in university rolls. He wm see that we have increased the number from about 6,000 to about 24,000 and, in the period from 1952 to 1968 improved the percentage from about 25% to 28%.
- 1 heard the Minister's argument. He still has not stated the number of applications.

- We regard the number of applications as a false guide. The honourable senator will find the figures strewn over the pages of Hansard in response to specific questions in another place. 1 wo li I'd urge that he no longer use false guides.
- The Minister says that they are false. We do not.

- Quite so. The next point to be made was that there was a great delay in announcing scholarships. I would like it to be understood by the honourable senator, because dissemination of criticism that has really no sound foundation is mischievous, that the majority of our scholarships are awarded after public examinations. lt is not possible to announce our scholarships until the public examination authorities have announced their decisions but we and the State education authorities are constantly exploring ways and means of getting the examination results out earlier. We say that our record is not too bad. For instance, in New South Wales this year the open entrance university and advanced education scholarships were announced on 1 0th January, 2 days after the relevant public examination results. Secondary scholarships were announced on 16th January, I day after the relevant public examination results. Technical scholarships for which selection is more complex, were announced 7 days after the last relevant examination results were published. The position in other States compares favourably with this. So 1 would have thought that that effort should in future escape criticism. Senator McClelland, as reported at page 1038 of Hansard, instanced a case in which a girl student had made an application, waited for information and then found that the position had been filled. Students have to recognise that to gain admission to institutions they may have to apply in advance of the publication of results in the same way as they have to apply in advance for scholarships.

speech.para: I do npt intend to go through each individual speech but I am sure that the Senate will be patient enough whilst one makes any reference to individual speeches which one thinks their content and courtesy demand. I should like to be permitted to refer to Senator Dame Ivy Wedgwood's speech, first of all incorporating a reference to the Scholarship Board to which Senator Webster also referred. The Scholarship Board is being abolished under this legislation. I shall ensure that the comments of my two colleagues whom I have named are brought to the Minister's attention. 1 have no doubt that he will give consideration to their viewpoint with regard to the establishment of some other authority, but they will note what I said in the second reading speech in that respect. It is not an undertaking to substitute a new board or a new committee, but consideration will be given to it and, flowing with that is an invitation to any senator who has a viewpoint on the subject to be good enough to address it to the Minister individually by letter. This would enable him to consider it on that basis.

Senator DameIvy Wedgwood also referred to the various scholarships. I wish to say only that she gave a much more detailed enumeration of the scholarships and the benefits than was given in any other speech in the Senate, and anybody who may be interested could refer to that description with advantage. She also mentioned this question of ministerial responsibility and said that the Minister must have some discretion to prevent injustice by reason of an unreasonable application of strict regulations in special cases. Senator Webster referred to that in much more comprehensive terms. He was good enough to suggest that the principle that he was advocating could be found expressed in my speech on a similar Bill in 1965.

talk.start.para: - Not in those words.

- No, not in those words. J just want to take a little time, because great damage can be done by a misconception of this principle by those who seek to undermine it and those who seek to maintain it. Great damage can be done by a misunderstanding either above or below the line.
- And by walking on a tight rope,
- No, not at all. This is a broad highway, the middle of which can be travelled easily by those who can either read or run.
- Senator Webster was on the opposite side of the argument.

- If interjections are to displace my explanation we shall continue to be fogged. There are certain matters which a Minister exists to administer. That is his very purpose. It would be an insult to the parliamentarians to suggest that they, collectively assembled in Parliament, should have to attend to matters such as the approval of the content of an individual or particular course. But there are other matters which are the subject of a rule of law and, if they are of a detailed nature, our practice is to put them in subordinate legislation. I refer to regulations which, we have been forcibly reminded, not only in past years but also in recent times, this Senate is vigilant to supervise.

speech.para: When we come to the conditions of eligibility for a scholarship and the benefits to be provided by a scholarship, they are matters of definition by regulation. But, looking at clause 5, for example, which states that 'scholarships, to be known as Commonwealth Secondary Scholarships, may, subject to and in accordance with the regulations, be granted by the Minister' for Senator Webster to say that this is a case of undue authority being left to the Minister is to show that he fails in a marked degree to give a proper understanding to the words 'subject to and in accordance with the regulations'. After the passage of this Bill no other scholarships may lawfully be granted by the Minister; he may grant only those provided for by the regulations.

talk.start.para: - Why the word 'may' and not 'shall'?

- Because the Parliament never fixes appropriations by regulation and the Minister has to quantify the number of scholarships that will comply with the regulations by reference to the annual appropriation of Parliament. Therefore, we authorise him to issue the scholarships in accordance with that mechanism. I come then to the next instance referred to by Senator Webster, that is, in subclause (2.).
- Before doing so would the Minister refer to line 5 of that clause which refers to -a course of secondary education at a level approved by the Minister for the purposes of this section.'?

- 1 had not intended to refer to every line mentioned by the honourable senator. I was conscious of the fact that a speech of this sort is a little difficult to listen to and 1 was endeavouring to spare him.
- Will the Minister deal with line 5?

- I shall accept the honourable senator's invitation in the cordial fashion in which it was extended. This is a reference to 'a course of secondary education at a level approved by the Minister for the purposes of this section'. The words to be emphasised are 'at a level approved by the Minister'. I. have called attention to the fact that in clause 6 in relation to Commonwealth technical scholarships the phrase is any course approved by the Minister', and that in clause 7 in relation to Commonwealth advanced scholarships the expression is 'any course approved by the Minister'. In each case they are courses approved by the Minister. I thought that my previous reference to them would have been sufficient on that point.

speech.para: As to individual courses proposed by an educational institution, considered by the Department and approved by the Minister, they may be so varied that each individual course should be approved by the Minister and could not possibly be the subject of any meaningful regulation. If I may be permitted to refer now to sub-clause (2.) of clause 5, it will be seen that a secondary school includes 'any educational institution in

Australia which, under a direction of the Minister, is to be treated as a secondary school'. In that instance the direction of the Minister is simply to say that he decides that he will regard an educational institution as a secondary school. Schools vary so much in their composition that whereas some persons might not call an institution a secondary school, for the purpose of these scholarships we leave it to the Minister's judgment to identify the school.

The point 1 wish to make in this regard is that matters of administration are traditionally left to the approval or direction of the Minister. Those who peruse his annual report to Parliament will, in conjunction with their general knowledge derived from their contact with their own electors, be able to judge whether any error has crept into his administrative functions throughout the year. But the Minister will be subject to subordinate legislation, that is, regulations, in all matters where it is possible in a purposeful sense to prescribe a rule as to the terms of eligibility and the entitlement by way of benefit. Those are the substantial contents of each of the scholarships and I have no doubt that that is the intended content of the regulations. 1 would point out that, subject to what 1 have said as to the terms of the Bill, the content of the regulations will be a matter for the judgment of this chamber when it comes to supervise the regulations.

talk.start.para: - Does the Minister intend to refer to clause 1 8 (2.)?

- Yes. I am obliged for the reminder. I mention first that clause 18(1.) simply permits the Minister to revoke an approval, direction or determination that he had made. If he has found that circumstances have changed in relation to a high school between one year and the. next he may give a direction appropriate to the changed circumstances. I am obliged to the honourable senator for referring to sub-clause (2.) because, in doing so, he failed to emphasise that here the word shall' is used. He failed to emphasise also that the words 'public notice' are used. If one looks at the emphasis upon the subclause one will perceive that the Minister shall make such arrangements as he think proper'.
- That is the term that I want the Minister to deal with.
- The honourable senator will never find me trying to jump over any difficulty. The sub-clause says:

quote.para: The Minister shall make such arrangements as he thinks proper for giving public notice of the giving or making by him under this Act of any approval, direction or determination or of any variation or revocation by him of such an approval direction or determination.

speech.para: So in the regulations would appear public notice of his rules and authority to annul them. In his administrative capacity he shall make such arrangements as he thinks fit to give public notice of these matters, but that is subject to clause 20 which requires him to prepare a report in regard to all those matters and submit it to the people's representatives annually. Further, he shall give public notice and, when, that annual report is reviewed, if anybody in this chamber criticises him and says that he is not exercising his discretion properly in deciding the arrangements he thinks proper or that he has failed in his duty, he is then subject to the impact that Parliament can make on a Minister. Of course, speaking as a Minister, one is always very conscious and respectful of that. May I on the other hand notice the comment that was made by Senator Webster with regard to interference with State functions. 1 regret that my colleague chose to express himself in that language, and I regret that he showed no more enthusiasm for our educational performance than to say that he did not necessarily agree that our performance was to the detriment of State educational activities. I would have wished that he had found it within his soul to say that he enthusiastically supported - not interference - but the supplementary assistance that has been forthcoming from the Federal Government to supply the deficiencies in the State performance notwithstanding the fact that there had been a very great increase in the performance by the States.

At the beginning of my speech, I pointed out that over the last 7 years the States had increased their appropriations for education from $225m to $646m. I would have wished that we on the Government side were unanimously of the opinion that there was no doubt as to the contribution from this Government being a detriment to State performance. 1 would have wished that we were enthusiastically of the opinion that this supplementary assistance from the Federal Government had been of great advantage to the Slates.

For myself, I would hope that it is fully understood that in the actual administration of the Commonwealth's policy in the education field the Minister and his Department - the Department of Education and Science - are zealous to obtain, by consultation at all times, the co-operation of the. State education officers, departments and Ministers. I believe there are very few educationists in the State sphere who do not look upon the activities of the Federal Government in this respect as helpful and co-operative, and 1 think very few would be found who would not appreciate it. Certainly there would be very few found who would resent what the Commonwealth has done as being interference with State functions. Senator Laucke made a contribution to the debate in a general sense, which 1 appreciate very much.

May I say in conclusion that, by reason of its framework the Bill gives great satisfaction to the Senate. When we consider that an appropriation of $29m this year will be regulated and administered under this legislation. 1 think it should give us satisfaction as a parliament that we have a framework by means of which, either in the Act or the regulations, the substantive provisions of these scholarships will appear for all interested to read. I submit that we shouldtake great satisfaction from the knowledge that the appropriation for scholarships in the Federal sphere in the last 7 years has increased from $6m to $29m. I submit also that we should take great satisfaction from the knowledge that the Government has performed in this way on an increasing scale so as to expand its appropriations up to date and from the knowledge that it has been a pioneer in the various fields in the world of education. Particularly do I refer to the aid that it has given to independent schools. The particular satisfaction that we get is from the knowledge that the Government is quite conscious of the fact that the whole job has not yet been done and that it is eager to make advances in the future comparable with its past performances. I ask the Senate to accept the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
