talk.start.para: - I want to draw the Committee's attention only to the fact that there are in these clauses some very significant improvements on the position that obtained in the 1967 Bill. In each of clauses 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9, scholarships are granted subject to and in accordance with regulations. I make the point, which should go on the record of the Senate, since the Minister for Works (Senator' Wright) is at such pains to place matters on record, that the protections provided were completely omitted from the 1967 legislation and that they are included in this legislation because the Senate insisted upon them going in. Otherwise, it would not have been prepared to pass the Bill.

speech.para: The other matter to which I wanted to refer in dealing with these clauses is the expression in clauses 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9 that scholarships 'may be granted' to persons, and so on. When senators seek the information, 1 think they are entitled to know to whom and in what categories these scholarships are granted. I am very concerned about an answer that I received from the Minister for Education and Science (Mr Malcolm Fraser), through the Minister representing him in this chamber telling me deliberately that information which I sought was not available, without any promise of its being made available within a reasonable time and without any promise to get it. I had sought information related to the number of awards made to students attending each State secondary school and the name and location of each school and the same particulars with regard to non-government schools. I also wanted information as to how many open entrance university scholarships, secondary school scholarships and scholarships to attend colleges of advanced education had been awarded, together with particulars as to the number of students from each school who were awarded the scholarships. All I received was a simple statement that the Minister is looking into the question as to whether it might be possible to compile this information in future years.

I tell the Minister that I am just not satisfied with that. I do not regard it as proper to fob off in this way requests for information. If there is one thing we are entitled to know it is to whom these scholarships are going. We are also entitled to know what the pattern of distribution is between schools in the various areas and between government and non-government schools. 1 do not feel at all happy about just agreeing, to these clauses without having some assurance that something will be done to provide us with this information.

talk.start.para: - It is really encouraging to find a little spirit being injected into the debate at this stage by Senator Cohen. As to the question of regulations, 1. have already dealt with that in my reply to the second reading debate. The honourable senator rather menacingly shook a piece of paper across the table and said: lt is not good enough. 1 will not accept that'. I should like the Senate to know that the honourable senator put before us three questions. One was in relation to advanced education scholarships, one was in relation to secondary education scholarships and one was in relation to open entrance university scholarships. He wanted to know how many of these scholarships were given to Students attending each State secondary school, the name and the location of such school, how many awards were granted to students attending each non-government school and the name and location of that school.

speech.para: There is no requirement in the qualifications for the award of any of these scholarships that a scholar should come from a particular kind of school. A scholar simply submits to an examination. His results are examined and then, according to his qualifications, irrespective of the school, he is given, an award. Not only is it not useful for the Department of Education and Science to keep a record of the performance of each school but when lists are published - as, of course, all scholarship awards are published - the schools object to that form of publication. Of course, such objection would not govern us but we do have regard to it.

Having regard to the unjustified criticism that often is levelled in this place at the Government by the Opposition about delays in answering questions, I have given my Department instructions that we are to have regard to the volume of statistics we can collate within a reasonable time. If we have not got the i record I prefer to' teH , Senator Cohen, as 1 did, that the information is not -available. I thought it would be courteous to go on and say that the Minister, however, is looking into the question of whether it might be possible to compile this information in future years. 1 have pointed to its irrelevance. I have pointed out that the schools object to that form of publication for the purpose of general information but that, notwithstanding, we are considering the usefulness of getting figures .in this form. I therefore wish quite firmly to refute the suggestion that this is not. good enough. I submit it is entirely proper and 1 also submit that to propriety the answer adds courtesy.

talk.start.para: - 1 wish to direct attention to the need for a public examination . of the chaos in public, thinking on the subject of education. I recently attended a public meeting at Eastwood at which about 3,000 people stood up the politicians of the district over this matter of education. 1 was greatly impressed by the confusion on this subject. The meeting was called to hear addresses by Federal politicians, including the Commonwealth Attorney-General (Mr Bowen). However, those in attendance developed an attitude of open hostility to Mr Jago, the man who represented the Premier,' Mr Askin. I believe the p'eople were confused by federal propaganda on Federal aid for,' control of and interest in education. All they were worrying about was the State Minister, who was really responsible. Mr Jago was under criticism for three-quarters of the time. The person under fire was not Mr Whitlam, not the Federal member and not the Attorney-General,- because in the public mind education is a State matter. Senator Webster said much the same thing. There is great confusion over education.

speech.para: Clearly, the Minister believes that everything in the education garden is lovely. At the Commonwealth level we seem, to know where we are going in this field but the public does not. The Opposition is supporting this Bill but I think it would be in the interests of education if some sort of nonpolitical investigation were made into education generally in Australia, particularly during this period of change when State influence is weakening and Federal influence is strengthening. I ask the Minister for his view of this aspect. Does he not think that such a non-political investigation would be useful? Everybody involved in education would then know where they are going, including the people who get the advantages that (he Government might hand out and the States who receive payments from the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: - 1 desire to raise certain matters arising out of clauses 4 to 8. I do so because I share the view expressed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Cohen), both in his speech in the second reading debate and again more shortly today, with regard to the manner in which this Bill is to be operated, or the manner in which procedures provided by it are to be operated, in contrast with what was proposed some time ago. 1 also share the view expressed by the Minister for Works (Senator Wright) that the Senate should be ever vigilant. 1 recognise that the provisions to which I refer lay down a broad scheme in which the principle is set out and that much is to be left to the regulations or to administrative direction. I understand that the difference between this and the previous measure is that vastly more is to be left to regulations.

speech.para: I would be interested to know what the Minister for Works says is the full purport of the definition of full time student. On my reading of that definition a full time student is not a person who happens to be undergoing a course of study at a school, a university, a college of advanced education or a technical college but is simply a person included in a class definable by the Minister for Education and Science (Mr Malcolm Fraser). 1 would like the Minister to indicate whether my construction is correct and whether, therefore, the Minister for Education and Science has the power to determine who is or is not a student irrespective of whether he is studying at a university, a college or a school.

If the Minister has this power, what reason is there for denying a scholarship to a person who goes to a school, a university or institution in the expectation that he Will be eligible for a scholarship? That person may find that for some reason, either now or in the future, the particular course of study in which he is interested is, by ministerial direction, excluded from the benefits of scholarships. I appreciate that it will be the intention of the Minister to enlarge the field of scholarships, so far as he is able, but pursuing the vigilance which the Minister for Works exhorted us to observe, it seems appropriate to consider the language of the Bill with a view to determining whether that is an interpretation that is open to us.

The other aspect to which I wish to refer relates to clauses 5, 6, 7 and 8, which relate to secondary schools, technical colleges, advanced education institutions and universities and which provide that scholarships shall be granted by the Minister to persons who are undertaking or propose to undertake, courses as full time students. The crucial point is that the scholarships may by granted by the Minister - and I use the expression that is used in those clauses - subject to and in accordance with the regulations. There appear to me to be two interpretations open. I think that the correct one is that there must Be regulations and that any scholarship awarded must be subject to the regulations, but equally it may be arguable that if there are no regulations at all there is nothing to which the grant may be subject and the grant takes effect without being subject to anything whatever. I would be grateful tt the Minister would indicate - as 1 expect and hope he will - that the former of the two alternatives I put forward is the true position. I would also be grateful if he would elaborate, in the terms of these clauses, on his statement in the course pf his second reading speech that regulations will be made to deal with certain matters - for example, conditions of eligibility and methods of selection.

I think it is appropriate in the Committee stage to scrutinise closely the regulations to be made within the framework of the Act, and the operations of those regulations as envisaged by the Act, and to ensure that the regulations do not give too wide a power of discretion and that the field of operation of the regulations is specifically limited. I know that the Scholarships Regulations under the existing Education Act contain one clause and one clause alone, under which the whole scholarships scherzo seems to have operated, in terms of the power to grant scholarships. It is to elicit further information as to what the regulations are designed to cover that I ask these questions, and in pursuit, as 1 said, of the vigilance which the Minister encourages.

talk.start.para: - 1 would suggest that Senator Ormonde's observations were sufficiently referred to in my earlier reply and that I could not with advantage in the Committee stage elaborate any further on his views on the general question to which he referred. The first of Senator Greenwood's contributions related to clause 4 and the definition of a full time student. The reason why it is thought that the Minister should specify the students to whom the term 'full time' can be applied is because of the great variety of circumstance^ applicable to any student. For instance, on.student may be doing a particular toUrs. and another student may be doing only 90% of that course and have some job after 5 o'clock. The question whether a student is a full time student or not may have a different meaning according to whether the scholarship is -i technical one or a university one. A university student may have ancillary employment. Some people may say that he is not << full time student. All those circumstances. I submit, are properly to be determined in a case of doubt by the Minister and should be under his general supervision.

speech.para: The more important question to which my colleague, Senator Greenwood, referred wa: the expression in each of clauses 5, 6, 7. 8 and 9 that scholarships may be awarded subject to and in accordance with the regulations. I want to be as completely unequivocal as it is possible to be. My opinion is that the only possible interpretation of the language of the clauses is the first interpretation suggested by the honourable senator: that is, that unless there are regulations scholarships cannot be awarded and that any scholarships that are awarded must be subject to the conditions provided in those regulations. The kinds of matters that it is expected that the regulations will refer to are, firstly, the question of eligibility, which would include such things as age limits, residential qualifications, bonded students, previous study and educational qualifications; and, secondly, the question of selection. As far as practicable the regulations will cover selected methods for various scholarship schemes and for different classes of scholarships within each scheme - for example, open entrance, later year awards and so on. I may add that the regulations will also provide benefits to which successful students will be entitled - monetary or any other benefits that may accrue. 1 think that all those conditions of scholarships will be provided for.

In considering eligibility it follows, in my view, that the regulations will always hu expected to provide for cases in which scholarships may be forfeited or discontinued. ' lt is expected that because of different circumstances of individuals some discretion will be permitted by Parliament to reside in the Minister so that he can adjust iniquities that might otherwise occur. These might arise in cases df sickness or perhaps in the case of a student who might present grounds considered just outside the limit of reasonable or excusable grounds. I hope that statement agrees with the viewpoint of Senator Greenwood whose outlook on this matter is one for which. I have great respect.

Senator COHEN(Victoria) [4.221-1 think the second point raised by Senator Greenwood, which has just been discussed by the Minister, is a very important one. Without wanting to be overcritical of the Minister, I do not think we should leave the matter where he has left it. I appreciate and accept that the Minister has frankly and honestly expounded his own view of the meaning of these expressions. I go on record as saving that I agree with the view that scholarships cannot be awarded unless there are regulations. Equally there is another view which, as Senator Greenwood has said, may be open. With respect to the Minister, I think we need more than his assurance that what he understands the position to be, as a lawyer and . as the responsible Minister in this place giving the Senate his view of what interpretation should be placed upon the expression, is the position. I think we are entitled to expect something further. I think we are entitled to expect a categorical assurance that there will be regulations covering these matters. I think he should give a firm indication of the precise matters that the regulations will cover. The Minister - and I accept that this was said with complete candour by him - speculated or foreshadowed what might be the subject of regulations or what he, Senator Greenwood, myself and, I would imagine, all honourable senators who have taken part in this debate or in the debate on the earlier legislation, would expect to be the subject of regulations. I would not be disposed to let it rest without an indication from the Minister that this is the Government's intention.

talk.start.para: - It is.

- If it is. then it is different from what the Minister has said already as an indication of his own construction of the clause which happens to accord with one of the views that Senator Greenwood put.
- If I put a View in this House I would not' expect the Committee to accept from the Government any other view. ' .

- I cast no reflection on the Minister in accepting this but I think there is a distinction between what he, as the Minister representing the Minister for Education and Science, puts forward as his view of what would be regarded as things properly to be included in the regulations, and what we can act upon, because if there were the slightest doubt about any matter of construction at this stage 1 think that the Senate in Committee would want to deal with it.

- I thought that the honourable senator would take the explanation that I, as the responsible Minister in charge of the legislation, put forward as an explicit and definite statement of the view that would be adopted by the Government. Neither the Government nor i would expect the Senate to accept any other view. That is my function as the Minister in this chamber.
- And there will be regulations covering these matters?
- It is that after this legislation is passed no scholarships can bc awarded lawfully except in accordance with the regulations which, ex hypothesi, must be brought into existence.

speech.para: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 11 to 14 - by leave - taken together.

talk.start.para: - I wish to raise two matters. 1 think 1 referred to them both in my speech in the second reading debate when I indicated that I would be happy to accept the Minister's assurance and that we would spell it out at the Committee stage. So far as clauses 11 and 12 are concerned - 1 am interested in the matter because of the earlier debate we had - 1 wanted it to be quite clear that the word 'prescribed' in those clauses meant prescribed by the regulations. If that is the Minister's view I will accept it and will not pursue the matter further.
- That is the Government's view of the Bill.

- in relation to the second matter 1 merely seek some elucidation of a difference in language that exists between clauses 11 and 12 where the word prescribed' is used, and clauses 13 and 14 where the expression 'determined in accordance with the regulations' is used. I am interested to know whether there is any significance in the different language that is used.

- The difference in language results from the fact that in relation to secondary and technical scholarships the rate is fixed. In the other cases the living allowance is variable according to a means test.
- I am satisfied with that.

- I wish to refer to the prescribed amount. Although this Bill does not actually cover the amount I have been asked by some people in my State, particularly in the electorate of Forrest - 1 am referring now specifically to the Bridgetown area - to raise this matter. They find considerable difficulty in sending their children on Commonwealth scholarships to Perth because of the costs involved. The costs are covered, or supposed to be covered, by clause 1 1 (c) which prescribes a living allowance.

speech.para: The position in the Bridgetown area - I should like this to be noted when the prescribed rate is being determined at various times - is that the people have to send their children to a high school outside the area.

The nearest high school is at Manjimup but there is no way of getting there. So the children have to be sent to Perth. The costs involved have been worked out very carefully by farmers in the area. They are quite prepared to pay what it would cost them normally to keep their children at home and send them to the local secondary school if there were a local secondary school. The amount granted under the scholarship scheme to successful students is only about two-thirds of the additional amount required to meet their expenses. 1 know that the Bill does not lay down any allowance but f have been asked to bring this matter forward so that the Government might keep it in mind when consideration is being given to the prescribed amount for living allowance.

talk.start.para: - I will see that the matter is considered by the Minister for Education and Science.

speech.para: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 15 (Payment of benefits under scholarships).

talk.start.para: - 1 am concerned to ensure that we exercise the vigilance to which Senator Greenwood referred over the precise meaning of the language.
- The Minister invited the comment.
- There is no criticism of the Minister in this. He accepted your view. But I think you were the one who first used the word 'vigilance'. The clause reads:

quote.para: Benefits under a scholarship shall be paid at such times, in such manner and to such person, or to a person included in such class of persons, as the Minister determines.

speech.para: Left on its own and without the context of the Bill one would be very fearful that this was reintroducing what we sought to exclude in our battles on the 1967 legislation. That was the granting of unfettered discretion, recognising the need for discretion in certain cases. I ask the Minister whether this is to be understood as meaning as the Minister determines in accordance with the regulations'. If it is, why should we not have that language in the clause?

talk.start.para: - If the honourable senator turns to clause 10 he will see that benefits there are indicated to be:

item.para: . financial assistance to, or for the benefit qf, the holder of the scholarship.

speech.para: Clause 15 simply says that the Minister, like a shop manager, will say: 'I will pay my bills fortnightly or 3-monthly'. The scholar may wish the school to bc paid the scholarship benefit. These are purely detailed administrative matters such as occur in any office. Of course the Minister will be authorised to pay only such benefits as are provided by the regulations.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill - by leave- taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: - I rise to place on record the fact that clause 20 is in the Bill only because in 1967 the Opposition insisted that a clause be included requiring the Minister to report annually on the operation of the -legislation. When introducing the previous legislation the then Minister for Education and Science - now the Prime Minister (Mr Gorton) - referred to his intention to make an annual statement. The Opposition, supported by a number of honourable senators opposite, including the Minister for Works (Senator Wright), who is in charge of this legislation, insisted that this provision should be included in the legislation. I. pay tribute to the Minister for Works for his contribution to the debate on that occasion. The then Minister for Education and Science introduced his own amendment to put the matter right. That is why this clause is included in the Bill.

speech.para: Senator GREENWOOD(Victoria) [4.36J - 1 desire to raise matters concerning clauses 18 and 19. 1 notice that clause 18(1.) provides:

quote.para: An approval, direction or determination of tile Minister under this Act may be varied or revoked by the Minister.

speech.para: There is a wide range of matters upon which ministerial approvals, directions and determinations may be given. I appreciate that the Parliamentary Draftsman has included a provision for publicity to be given to what the Minister has done. I think this is always desirable in cases of this nature. But curious phraseology has been used. Clause 18 (2.) states:

quote.para: The Minister shall make such arrangements as he thinks proper for giving public notice of the giving or making by him under this Act of any approval, direction or determination or of any variation or revocation by him of such an approval, direction or determination.

speech.para: One might have supposed that there would be provision whereby such a notification would be included in the Commonwealth Gazette' if in no other place, or in the annual report required under clause 20. I ask the Minister: What is proposed and what is intended as the type of publicity the Minister will give under clause 18(2.)? It can be publicity which will achieve the purpose of making available information to anybody who is prepared to make a modicum of inquiry or it can be the simple sort of publicity which constitutes compliance with the legislation but in fact gives no information to anybody at all because it is too difficult to search out. The second point I wish to raise relates to clause 19, which provides for a power of delegation. That power is in the usual form used by the Parliamentary Draftsman. Clause 19 (1.) states:

quote.para: The Minister may, by instrument in writing, delegate to a person- 1 take no objection to the use of the words instrument in writing', but I would like to know what persons the Minister has in mind as persons to whom this power shall be delegated. I should imagine they are persons within the Department of Education and Science who can exercise this power, but one would think that propriety would indicate that delegation should be limited to officers of the Department. Is it intended that determinations relating to the granting of any of these scholarships, whether under the Act or the regulations, will be made by people outside the Department? I would think that it it is intended that persons envisaged under clause 19 shall include persons who are not officers of the Depart ment this would be a matter to attract tha concern of the Senate.

talk.start.para: - The intention is that the delegation shall, in general, be to officers of the Department of Education and Science. I have only one reservation to make in answer to Senator Greenwood's question. We know that several committees of an advisory nature have been set up under the education scheme. Having regard to what has been said about the substitution of a committee for the Scholarship Board, it may be that a committee of that sort would be a delegate in some respects, but I would think not. In any case. If such a step were to be made it would be a matter fit to be mentioned in the annual report.

speech.para: Senator Greenwoodalso referred to the question of the Minister making such arrangements as he . thinks proper for giving public notice of certain things. Nobody would suggest that the fact that, say, Jim Smith is a full time student should be notified in the Commonwealth Gazette' or in the annual report unless there is some suggestion of abuse. However there will be many cases in which it will be necessary to give public notice of the fact that a certain school is a secondary school. I suggest that those are the sorts of things that make it proper for the Minister to make such arrangements as he thinks fit to give public notice of a direction. I believe that that degree of discretion should be left to the Minister.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
